item.title: Fees | Asia responds to new US announcements
item.description: Several countries and regions in Asia reacted Saturday to the US Supreme Court's decision that annulled the tariffs imposed by the President, as well as the new 10 percent global tax that Donald Trump instituted after the court decision. Tokyo rules out that the invalidation of the rates will affect previously agreed investments, according to the economic newspaper Nikkei, while Taiwan and Hong Kong foresee a “limited” effect of the new global tariff. China has not yet commented. In response to the resolution, which invalidates the so-called “reciprocal tariffs” and other generalized taxes applied by Trump, with a minimum rate of 10 percent, the President signed a global tariff of 10 percent on all countries. The law that supports this new executive order only allows tariffs to be increased by up to 15 percent and for periods of 150 days, so it is not clear how it will be articulated in the long term, writes the EFE news agency. South Korea said the trade deal with Washington, which provides for commitments such as a $350 billion South Korean investment and 15 percent tariffs from Washington, remains intact. According to Yonhap news agency, South Korean authorities called an emergency meeting to assess the impact of invalidating the tariffs. The governments of Taiwan and Hong Kong consider that the 10 percent global tariff announced by Trump will have a “limited impact” on their economies. Indonesia, which on Thursday signed a trade agreement with the US, indicated that it will hold “new talks” with Washington in light of the “dynamics that are occurring”. Malaysia assured that it “will continue to diversify its trade relations and strengthen regional and multilateral economic cooperation”, despite the decision that invalidates a large part of Trump's tariffs.

item.title: STD | Portuguese market is a priority
item.description: The director of the Tourism Services (DST), Maria Helena de Senna Fernandes, said that Portugal will be one of Macau's priorities when it comes to attracting more foreign visitors. In a message broadcast by public broadcaster TDM – Teledifusao de Macau, regarding the Lunar Year of the Fire Horse, Senna Fernandes pointed out among the targets for this year “European markets, such as Portugal and Spain”. The director also mentioned Southeast Asia, Northeast Asia – a region that includes Japan, Mongolia and the Far East of Russia – and “the emerging tourist markets in the Middle East and Central Asia”. Senna Fernandes predicted that Macau will receive 41 million visitors in 2026, after reaching close to 40.1 million visitors last year, a new historic high. The majority (90.6 percent) of tourists came from Mainland China or Hong Kong. Tourism | Flat orders to encourage consumption Deputy Chan Lai Kei wants the Government to draw lessons from tourism statistics and visitor consumption patterns to implement measures that increase tourists' stay in Macau and commerce in residential neighborhoods off the tourist trail. In a written question, the deputy linked to the Fujian community indicated that during this Lunar New Year, the Government invested a lot of resources into organizing large events, which failed to benefit small and medium-sized companies in areas less popular with tourists. Chan Lai Kei argues that the Government should improve the transport system during national holiday periods, in order to facilitate visits to residential neighborhoods, far from the most popular tourism centers. The deputy also asked the Sam Hou Fai Executive for practical measures to improve the experiences of international tourists and eliminate current obstacles, such as the lack of international electronic payments and language barriers. Performance Venue | IC will launch new measures The president of the Cultural Affairs Bureau (IC), Deland Leong, revealed that the IC will launch an online platform for companies to consult rental requests for the Macau Open-Air Performance Venue. The changes are part of the Government's objectives to “expand and reinforce the functions” of the concert venue and were revealed on the morning program Forum Macau on the Chinese channel Rádio Macau. This objective had previously been revealed by the secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, during the presentation of the Lines of Government Action, in the Legislative Assembly. At that time, the secretary pointed out that in the future the space could receive 3×3 basketball courts or other facilities for family sporting activities. Deland Leong also acknowledged that the Government will review some of the regulations and guidelines for the use of the space.

item.title: Suicide | Cáritas Support Line received around 30 calls per day
item.description: Between the 16th and 19th of this month, the last three days of the last lunar year, the Caritas suicide prevention helpline entitled Caritas LifeHope received around 30 calls daily. The number was indicated by the person responsible for the telephone line, Ng Lai Ieng, cited by the newspaper Ou Mun. The person in charge explained that the number of daily calls was similar to that on other business days. Ng Lai Ieng revealed that seven of these calls were requests for help related to suicide, but fortunately they were nothing more than thoughts, without any type of planning or associated action. Ng pointed out that in these cases the calls are classified as low-risk cases. The other requests for help were motivated by marital conflicts or problems adapting to situations of divorce, stress, and other cases of mental and emotional instability. Anyone who is emotionally distressed or considers themselves to be in a desperate situation should call the Caritas Hope for Life Hotline on 28525222 in order to obtain emotional counseling services.

item.title: More Chinese New Year shows in the coming days
item.description: The Directorate of Tourism Services (DST) continues to organize, in the coming days, shows to celebrate the arrival of the Year of the Horse with fireworks. One of the initiatives is the holding of three editions of “2026 – Drone and Fireworks Shows”, where drones are introduced for the first time in this type of presentation, in a combination of “technology with art, increasing the sensation and appreciation of fireworks shows”, in order to “enrich festive experiences”. One of these presentations takes place today, the seventh day of Chinese New Year, and then on March 3, the fifteenth day of the first month of Chinese New Year. These shows take place in the bay next to the Macau Tower. Also noteworthy is the holding of the “Second parade of floats with cultural performances” on Saturday, the 28th, the 12th day of the Lunar New Year. Between 8pm and 9:30pm, and starting at Rua Norte do Patane, the parade also includes a cultural show in the Iao Hon Municipal Market Garden. There will be 17 floats in this parade, eight of them representing Government departments and the remaining nine from local tourist entities. The public will be able to watch this parade from its beginning, on Rua Norte do Patane, and along the pedestrian walkways on the parade route to the finishing point, in the Jardim do Mercado Municipal de Iao Hon. According to a note from DST, the aim is, “through installations characteristic of the festive season, to increase the festive atmosphere of the neighborhoods and the tourist attraction, attracting people to the community neighborhoods”. This “Gala galloping at ZAPE” has “the participation of ZAPE traders and several integrated tourism and leisure companies”, and includes the launch of promotional packages to attract more tourists.

item.title: Kart: new INHAME competition is born in Macau
item.description: It is next weekend that the Coloane Kartdrome will host the first of seven rounds of the most recent championship integrated into the IAME international family of karting competitions, the IAME Series Macau After the MSAR established itself as a mandatory stop on the IAME Series Asia calendar and the Macau International Karting Grand Prix hosted the IAME Asia Final, the launch of the IAME Series Macau was confirmed, even before the New Lunar Year, comprising seven races to be held in Coloane. The calendar presented follows the already established AAMC Karting Championship. According to the brief communication released on social media by IAME Asia Series, “Macau’s motorsport heritage is profound and its passion for racing is recognized worldwide”. For the IAME promoter on the Asian continent, based in Singapore, taking the competition to the Macao SAR constitutes “another decisive step in the growth of karting in Asia-Pacific, creating more routes, more opportunities and a stronger community for young talents”. All the same The IAME Series are karting championships organized under the aegis of the Italian IAME (Italian American Motor Engineering), one of the world's largest manufacturers of engines for the sport. The IAME Series Asia calendar will also be expanded next year: in addition to the rounds in Malaysia and Thailand, Macau will host the fourth of six races of the season, scheduled for the 23rd and 24th of May. Regardless of country or region, all participants compete with IAME engines, under uniform technical regulations that ensure equal conditions on the track. The model prioritizes cost control and competition sustainability, placing emphasis on individual talent and sporting equity. In addition to Macau and the Asian championship, IAME already promotes competitions in Mainland China, Japan, Malaysia, Thailand, Sri Lanka, India and the Philippines. In this context, the organization believes that “together, we continue to build an interconnected platform across the region”. As previously announced, the IAME Asia Final, covering all categories, will return for the third consecutive year to the Macau International Karting Grand Prix program. This year's edition is scheduled to take place between December 11th and 14th. As previously announced, the IAME Asia Final, for all categories, will return for the third consecutive year to the Macau International Karting Grand Prix program. item.title: Portugal | BNU and Misericórdia join the solidarity campaign
item.description: Six Portuguese-based entities in Macau and Hong Kong announced a fundraising campaign to help victims of the storms in Portugal. After Cáritas Macau, the solidarity wave encompasses BNU, Misericórdia, Casa de Portugal, Council of Portuguese Communities, Lusophone Scout Group of Macau and Club Lusitano After Cáritas Macau announced about two weeks ago that it was raising funds to help victims of the storms that affected Portugal and Spain in recent weeks, the solidarity campaign in Macau and Hong Kong was extended to six Portuguese-based entities. Monetary donations can go to an account at Banco Nacional Ultramarino (BNU), which has joined the initiative, according to a joint statement. The funds will then be redirected “to one or more Portuguese social solidarity institutions operating on the ground, ensuring transparency and traceability of the entire process”, they added in the same note. Recalling the “best tradition of fraternity and solidarity that unites Portuguese-speaking peoples”, the statement makes “a public appeal for the mobilization of the Portuguese-speaking community in Macau and the Greater Bay Area”. In addition to having the institutional support of the consulate, the campaign was launched by the Casa de Portugal association in Macau, the China Circle of the Council of Portuguese Communities and the Lusophone Scout Group of Macau. Long challenge In Hong Kong, the initiative has the participation of Club Lusitano, the largest institution of the Portuguese-descendant community of the former British colony, with around 400 members, founded in 1866. It is worth remembering that on February 10, the Catholic organization Cáritas Macau launched a three-month fundraising campaign for those affected by the storms in the Iberian Peninsula. In a note published on social media, the Catholic organization lamented the “devastating storms” that caused “catastrophic floods” and landslides in Portugal and Spain, destroying infrastructure and homes. "Thousands of people are homeless and urgently need water, food and medical care. Local teams work tirelessly, but the recovery will be long and challenging", warned Cáritas Macau. On Wednesday, the União das Misericórdias Portuguesas said it had received a donation worth 300 thousand euros from Misericórdia de Macau to support its counterparts who suffered significant damage caused by the Kristin depression. Nineteen people died in Portugal following the Kristin, Leonardo and Marta depressions, which also caused many hundreds of injuries and displacement. The total or partial destruction of homes, businesses and equipment, the fall of trees and structures, the closure of roads, schools and transport services, and the cut of energy, water and communications, floods and floods are the main material consequences of the storm. The Centre, Lisbon and Vale do Tejo and Alentejo regions were the most affected. The calamity situation that covered the 68 most affected municipalities ended on February 15th.

item.title: Birth rate | Expected rate increase of 4.5 percent
item.description: After visiting the first babies of the Year of the Horse, Tai Wa Hou indicated that the expected increase is due to the fact that the Government has launched “high quality services” to promote birth rates The leader of the public hospital predicted that there should be more than three thousand births in 2026, an increase of at least 4.5 percent, in the region with the lowest birth rate in the world. According to the Chinese language channel of public broadcaster TDM Macau, the deputy director of Centro Hospitalar Conde de São Januário said he was confident that young couples in the territory would have more children. After visiting the first babies born in the Lunar Year of the Fire Horse, which has now begun, Tai Wa Hou defended that the Government launched “high-quality services” to promote birth rates. In July, the local parliament approved a budget review to reinforce social support, including the creation of a subsidy, worth a total of MOP54,000, for children up to three years old. The Government also launched a public consultation on the increase, in the private sector, of maternity leave, from 70 to 90 days, and annual leave, from six to 12 days to “obtain a better balance between work and family life”. The mother of the first baby of the year, born at 00:11 in Conde de São Januário, surnamed Fung, told TDM that she plans to have more children and hopes that the newborn will grow up with “many siblings”. The estimate made by Tai Wa Hou still represents a drop compared to the forecast made almost a year ago, also on the first day of the Lunar New Year. Black numbers On January 29, 2025, the deputy director of Macau Health Services, Kuok Cheong U, predicted that the year would end with fewer than 3,500 births. On January 1st, Tai Wa Hou revealed that Macau registered 2,871 newborns in 2025, the lowest number in almost 50 years, since 1978, when the city, then under Portuguese administration, registered 2,407 newborns. However, while in 1978 Macau had less than 249 thousand inhabitants, at the end of September 2024 the region already had a population of almost 687 thousand. The number of births thus fell for the sixth consecutive year and is increasingly far from the historic maximum of 7,913, set in 1988. Macau recorded just 0.58 births per woman in 2024, far from the value needed to replace generations (2.1), the lowest fertility rate ever in the region and the lowest in the world, according to official data.

item.title: Borders | Secretary wants security against external forces
item.description: The Secretary for Security promised that the region will strengthen border security in 2026, “to avoid interference from external forces”. Chan Tsz King highlighted the importance of collaboration with secret agencies in Mainland China and Hong Kong The Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, committed to strengthening security at Macau's border posts throughout this year, “to avoid interference from external forces”, but without pointing out any threats. “We will further enhance security surveillance at sea and land ports to prevent interference from external forces,” Chan told public broadcaster TDM – Teledifusao de Macau. In a message regarding the Lunar Year of the Fire Horse, which began last week, the leader did not identify the threats coming from abroad, but promised to “fully safeguard national security”. “We will continue to strengthen our intelligence collection and analysis capabilities, especially through ongoing intelligence exchanges with mainland China and Hong Kong,” Chan Tsz King also said. In November, the secretary promised to create, in 2026, a risk warning system against national security and warned against “acts of interference and destruction” by “external forces”. Dangerous discord On July 31, Macau police announced the arrest of former deputy Au Kam San, a Portuguese citizen, in the first case under the national security law. On February 5, the director of the Judicial Police assured journalists that there was sufficient evidence to justify Au Kam San's arrest. “There is a lot of evidence and we are entering the trial process, so we cannot disclose the details,” said Sit Chong Meng. Three days earlier, human rights organization Human Rights Watch said Au Kam San's case illustrates the “erosion of autonomy and fundamental freedoms” in Macau. In November, the head of the European Union (EU) Delegation in Hong Kong and Macau wrote on social media that he had met with Macau's Secretary for Economy and Finance, Anton Tai Kin Ip. “I also expressed concern about political issues,” added Briton Harvey Rouse. But the EU representation declined to reveal to Lusa whether the case against Au Kam San was mentioned at the meeting. In September, during a visit to Macau, Prime Minister Luís Montenegro admitted that he did not discuss the detention of the Portuguese citizen with the territory's leader, Sam Hou Fai. “There are some issues that also deserve some modesty in their treatment and this is one of them”, defended the prime minister.

item.title: New Year | Sam makes “wishes of peace and prosperity to the great country”
item.description: The Chief Executive entered the Year of the Fire Horse with desires for national prosperity and pointed to “new horizons” for Macau, under the “firm” leadership of President Xi Jinping In the traditional speech to enter the Lunar New Year, the Chief Executive left wishes for “peace and prosperity to the great Fatherland”. The message was conveyed in a recorded video, released on the eve of the Lunar New Year. "The bell for the Year of the Horse will ring. At this moment, Spring is felt in all its splendor in Macau and this pearl shines incessantly in the palm of the motherland's hand", said Sam Hou Fai. “I wish peace and prosperity to the great country; to the MSAR, I wish stability and prosperous development; to all the residents of Macau, I wish you happiness and good health,” he added. Regarding the entry into the new year, the ruler stated that the “horse symbolizes loyalty, courage, exploratory spirit and freedom” and that these qualities “must be promoted” to face “the future”. “Ahead of the Year of the Horse, we must, with a spirit of leadership, courage and perseverance, promote the development of Macau in all aspects in the best possible way; we must, with persistence and dedication, continue to adequately carry out work to improve the lives of the population for their well-being”, he highlighted. Get stronger In the message, the Chief Executive also highlighted the need for the Macao SAR and the country to continue to strengthen themselves to achieve new successes. “As the Chinese quote says: ‘The movement of heaven is vigorous; therefore, a noble person must strive tirelessly to strengthen himself’”, he stressed. "The success story of the 'One Country, Two Systems' principle in the Macao SAR has been written generation after generation by the people of Macau. I am convinced that, under the firm leadership of Mr. President Xi Jinping and the Central Government, counting on the great Motherland as unwavering support, as long as we have the courage to reform and innovate, better leveraging the institutional advantages of the 'One Country, Two Systems' principle, we will certainly be able to achieve success, opening up new horizons of development and creating new splendid successes”, pointed out the leader of the Macao SAR Government.

item.title: Heritage | Stories of the stores on Rua Cinco de Outubro told in a book
item.description: Natalie Fu has just released a book about traditional commerce on Rua Cinco de Outubro, at the invitation of the Macau Cultural Heritage Reinvention Studies Association. “Macao’s Historical House Taxonomy – The Shophouses at the Rua Cinco de Outubro” tells the centuries-old story of shophouses that were the “heart of Macau’s Chinese community” A book has just been published that reveals a little about the history of commerce carried out by the Chinese community on Rua Cinco de Outubro, located in Porto Interior, the scene of many commercial movements over the centuries. The work also explains how these stores, which are at the same time houses, reveal details about the history of Macau. “Macao’s Historical House Taxonomy – The Shophouses at the Rua Cinco de Outubro”, written by Natalie Fu, a doctoral student at the University of São José, was invited by the Association for Studies on the Reinvention of Cultural Heritage of Macau, whose edition also depends on “the support and assistance of many other people”, the author told HM. One of the book's sales outlets, which does not have a Portuguese version, is Pin-to Livros. “The investigation began with the love for Macau and its old buildings”, reveals the author, who began the research work around these buildings in 2022, in the middle of the pandemic. "Rua de Cinco de Outubro has always been an important commercial area in Macau. Once, it was the heart of Macau's Chinese community. Even today, many old stores remain close to the local neighborhood. The stores are mixed-use buildings", explains the author. This is the stage for commercial diversity, as Rua Cinco de Outubro “is home to several businesses, such as traditional Chinese bakeries, Chinese medicine stores, tea shops and fruit shops”. According to the presentation of the work, made on social media by the association itself, this type of property constitutes “a common type of multifunctional residential building”, where the “plan of the buildings is generally rectangular, with two to three floors”. Typically, the ground floor is used for the store or as a warehouse, while the upper floors are reserved for housing. "This type of construction can adapt to the local climate, presenting great flexibility in the construction methods and materials used. Due to the diversity of daily uses, shop houses were once the main type of building on the streets of Macau, having important historical, social, cultural, architectural and aesthetic value", it further reads. Preservation Challenges Still according to the same note, the book draws attention to the importance of preserving this type of construction and, consequently, a symbol of local heritage. “Unfortunately, because they are small-scale and scattered buildings, and because they are not fully protected by the Macau Heritage Protection Law, they have been gradually disappearing with the rapid development of society”, and, currently, “only a small number of these buildings have the classification of ‘monument’ and are protected”. For Natalie Fu, “the preservation of Macau's stores faces many challenges, one of which is the fact that they are not included in the existing list of protected old buildings in Macau”, in addition to that, in her view, “changes in construction laws have also made it difficult to maintain these old buildings”. Asked about the future of this iconic street in Porto Interior, the author recognizes that “the growth of a city inevitably involves the renovation and disappearance of buildings”, so “determining which buildings should be preserved and how to preserve them is a long-term challenge”. Natalie Fu even talks about the need to extend the investigation to more streets in Macau that are also traditional shopping areas. "Research and documentation of the stores on Rua Cinco de Outubro and in Macau are urgent as their number is dwindling. Additionally, additional academic investigations and discussions with the local community are needed to inform the future direction of the Inner Harbor area." In relation to the panorama on Rua Cinco de Outubro, the author describes that maintenance should be focused on, keeping commercial spaces open. "Stores that are kept in use better highlight their social value. Taking some stores on Rua Cinco de Outubro as an example, the existence of century-old stores further emphasizes the cultural and historical value of the area and the stores. Furthermore, 'keeping them in use' allows for more immediate monitoring and maintenance, which is the most direct way of protecting ancient architecture." A certain influence In a territory characterized by the coexistence of Portuguese and Chinese cultures, Natalie Fu's book shows how these houses were influenced by other cultures. “Chinese and Western architecture in Macau have always influenced each other throughout historical development, and this feature is particularly visible in the appearance of the shop houses.” In this way, this book helps to cement this characteristic, “establishing a classification system for Macau’s shop houses, consolidating their architectural definition”. This book is, therefore, a “classifying study of the old shop houses in Macau”, constituting “the first step towards their safeguarding”, describes, in the same note, the association that supported the editorial and research project. "The author carried out a detailed record and survey [of the stores], starting with visits and cartography surveys in the Porto Interior area. Maps were drawn up of the location of the shop houses on that street, analysis sheets based on fieldwork, photographic records and interviews with current traders and residents, in order to understand the history of the use of each building." Furthermore, the work documents seven cases in particular, “providing information on their history, evolution and current use, as well as a preliminary discussion on possible preservation directions”. The book also records two examples of shop houses that have now disappeared. “It is hoped that this work will encourage more people to discover the ‘beauty of Macau.’ With the shop houses as a central theme, it is expected to promote exchange and discussion between academics from different areas”, the association also points out. Natalie Fu invited “several experts and academics to share their ideas, experiences and suggestions on the protection and future of this type of buildings”, it is described. Born and raised in Macau, Natalie Fu had the opportunity to visit all of Southeast Asia from a young age, trips that led her to “foster a deep appreciation and passion for architecture”. The author has a degree in Architecture, also describing herself as a person interested in the area of ​​heritage conservation and a “historical architecture scholar trained in Macau”.

item.title: Concert | “Classics on Strings” in March at CCM
item.description: March will be the time to host the “Clássicos em Cordas” concert, led by the Macau Orchestra, and which brings two violinists to the territory: Julian Rachlin and Sarah McElravy. Here's the opportunity to hear interpretations of compositions by Beethoven and Felix Mendelssohn Bartholdy The Macau Orchestra (OM) will be the protagonist of another classical music concert scheduled for March, namely on the 14th, and which will be performed in the large auditorium of the Macau Cultural Center (CCM). The concert will be directed by Julian Rachlin, considered a “world-renowned violinist”, as described in a note from the Cultural Institute (IC), which supports the show. Violinist Sarah McElravy also joins the stage. “String Classics” is the name of this show, which presents “a true feast of fascinating works for strings”, such as Beethoven’s “Coriolanus Overture”, Mozart’s “Symphony Concertante in E-flat Major” and “Symphony No. 3 in A Minor ‘Scottish'” by Feliz Mendelssohn Bartholdy, German composer and pianist. This last composition dates from 1829 and 1841, having been premiered in the city of Leipzig on March 3, 1842. It is one of the last major works composed by this master of Romanticism, with its composition beginning on a trip to Scotland. In the case of Beethoven's “Coriolanus Overture”, it lasts eight minutes and had its premiere in Vienna, in March 1807, and is known for having inaugurated two concert formats in the 19th century, namely the concert overture and the symphonic poem. Distinguished names In a note from the IC, the career of Julian Rachlin, born in Vienna, is described as an “internationally acclaimed Austrian violinist and violist”. Rachlin also collaborated “with numerous orchestras and several internationally renowned conductors for more than three decades”, and, in recent years, he was Principal Guest Conductor of the Royal Northern Sinfonia, in the United Kingdom. He also directed several international orchestras, such as the Oslo Philharmonic Orchestra and the Munich Philharmonic. Sarah McElravy, a Canadian violin and viola player, has performed on stage in Europe, America and Asia. She is “recognized for her exceptional technique, having collaborated with renowned orchestras and participated in several music festivals”. McElravy is seen as someone with “profound performance experience”, also dedicating herself “to promoting musical education, having founded a chamber music association in Mexico to bring world-class concerts to local communities”. The “Clássicos em Cordas” concert will last approximately one and a half hours, including an intermission. Tickets are now on sale, with prices ranging between 150 and 300 patacas.

item.title: Thailand | Virus kills 72 tigers in wildlife park
item.description: Authorities in northern Thailand said 72 tigers have died in recent weeks at a wildlife park due to a viral and bacterial infection. The tests detected the presence of the highly contagious canine distemper virus, as well as bacteria that affect the respiratory system, the Chiang Mai Provincial Livestock Department said in a statement on Friday. "When tigers get sick, it is more difficult to detect the disease than in animals like cats or dogs. By the time we realized they were sick, it was too late," said the director of Thailand's Department of Livestock, Somchuan Ratanamungklanon, to local media. The cats belonged to the privately owned Tiger Kingdom wildlife park. Tourists can “hug, touch and take up-close photographs with the tigers” there, according to the park's website. “These tigers died as they lived: in suffering, captivity and fear,” animal rights organization PETA Asia told France-Presse news agency. “If tourists avoided these places, they would quickly become unviable and tragedies like this would be much less likely to occur,” the organization added.

item.title: Health | Registration open for training in clinical medicine
item.description: Registration for the “training course in basic clinical medicine skills” is open until March 4th”, the Health Services said on Friday. The course, organized jointly with Hospital das Ilhas and Hospital Kiang Wu, aims to “raise the level of healthcare services”, “promote the synergistic development of public and private healthcare systems”, and “improve the technical capabilities and competitiveness of healthcare professionals in Macau”. This training course will be taught by doctors from the Health Services, and from the Islands and Kiang Wu hospitals, with a program focused on the systematic introduction to basic clinical medicine skills for generalists and resident doctors. 50 vacancies will be available for professionals interested in becoming general practitioners or resident doctors in public or private hospitals in the region. The training sessions are scheduled for the weekends between the 7th and 22nd of March in the multifunction room of the Macau Medical Academy, in the Dynasty Plaza Building, in Alameda Dr. Carlos d’Assumpção, Macau. The courses will be taught in Chinese.

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Confucius (c.551-c.479 BC), according to what is written in the Analects (Lunyu), exclaimed one day: «How bad I have been! It's been a long time since I dreamed of the Duke of Zhou", which would only initially be understood as a lament about the loss of ideals but later taken literally, given the way his name captured the imagination of subsequent generations. Ji Dan, the Duke of Zhou, or Zhou Gong Dan, the philosopher who was regent at the beginning of the Zhou dynasty (r.1042-1035 BC), would already be an idealized figure of a master of thought who would have contributed to the elaboration of basic concepts such as the Heavenly Mandate to justify imperial power or participated in the most important texts that express the unique national perspective on the World and correct human conduct in it, such as the I Ching, the Classic of poetry (Shijing) or the book of Rites of Zhou (Zhouli). His name also appears as an initial symbolic author, to give him authority, linked to a Zhougong Jiemeng dream interpretation manual, which would initially be an aid for decision-making by leaders, but whose current version dates back to the Tang dynasty (618-907), adding divination, philosophy and popular culture. There you can find methods of oneiromancy such as fanmeng which performs the reverse interpretation of a dream; if it has distressing content it will obtain favorable results, or chaizi, the play on words that derives hidden meanings from them. If they were often dismissed as superstition, in certain periods dreams took on special importance. During the Ming dynasty, a high-ranking court official named Xu Xianqing (1537-1602) wanted to leave his autobiography to posterity in a precise and concrete way, requesting the help of two painters known for their refined realistic method of portraying buildings, clothing and situations, which included two dreams. Yu Shi and Wu Yue made this album from 1588 (twenty six double sheets, ink and color on silk, 62 x 58.5 cm, in the Palace Museum in Beijing) an enlightening document about the life and places in which a high-ranking official moved at that time. Each situation shown is accompanied by poems, comments or reflections written by the biographer himself, who says exactly how old he was when it occurred. In the first, he was twelve years old, his mother died and the boy is seen awake next to his sleeping father, dreaming of his mother standing by the door. In the fifteenth situation, the title says: «Dreaming about Confucius and convalescing», the 45-year-old employee is lying on the bed from which he emerges, like a balloon, another situation where Confucius is represented in a car. Volitional dreams that speak of filial love and loyalty to the Ming, the objective finally expressed in the title Huanji, «Traits of a public servant».

item.title: Ana Cristina Alves
item.description: Ana Cristina Alves – Assistant Researcher and Coordinator of the Educational Service of the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center When listening to the Lecture on the Year of the Horse by Professor Wang Suoying at the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center regarding Chinese astrology and, specifically, the Fire Horse, which will inaugurate a new zodiacal period from February 17, 2026, I was able to recall some of the essential characteristics of the horse, transmitted by Chinese folk wisdom. Thus the horse begins to mythologically combine with the dragon in Dragon-Horse (龙马Lóngmǎ). This is an ideal combination, both on a mental and aesthetic level. From a spiritual point of view, the pair allows access to the organization of the world guided by intuitive wisdom, since it was on the back of this animal that the first legendary Chinese emperor Fuxi (伏羲) discovered the eight trigrams, fundamental for understanding the world. Let us remember them: the Creative Heaven (乾 Qián), the Receptive Earth (坤 Kūn), the abyssal Water (坎Kǎn), the clinging Fire (离 Lí), the awakening Thunder or Lightning (震 Zhèn), the gentle and penetrating Wind (巽 Xùn), the Joyful Lake (兑Duì) and the tranquil Mountain (艮 Gě) . These eight trigrams, with the qualities already mentioned, gave rise to the 64 hexagrams that make up the Classic of Changes, as I have already had the opportunity to mention, for example, in the text A Mulher na China (2007) or in the poetic work Visitações (2022). Through the composition of the trigrams into hexagrams, a world is exposed that poetically unfolds, depending on the intuitive and imaginative capabilities of each person, with precepts open to past, but also present and future existential experiences. Each person will be able to find what they are looking for at the same time as they create and recreate themselves with the help of the real elements of Heaven, Earth, Fire, Water and all others that they consider useful for their existential path, also traced with the help of the mind and, above all, the imagination. Still in its connection with the dragon in the proverbial expression “the Spirit of the Dragon-Horse” (龙马精神Lóngmǎ jīngshén) it represents the realization of an aesthetic ideal full of energy, beauty and power of transformation, just as these animals are for the Chinese. It starts, however, from a concrete floor and then flies. The land of popular wisdom tells us that the horse is a noble and loyal animal, which knows the path (老马识途Lǎomǎ-shítú), since experience is the mother of wisdom in it, but it is not just any experience: it is energetic, a good friend and loyal. This loyalty and energy could not be more noble, especially since since Chinese antiquity, equids have been the faithful companions of nobles. Therefore, the horse (马mǎ) also appears associated in language with nobility (侯hòu) and, through a game of homophonies, with the monkey (猴hóu), hence if in a painting the monkey appears on top of the horse, it means the possibility of receiving an honorific title, that is, of elevating the status. A horse can develop a lot of energy, with the most capable being those who travel a thousand miles (千里马Qiānlǐmǎ), whether equine or human, because there are also people overflowing with capacity and energy, like these animals, with those who had the blessing of being born under the good auspices of the Horse being in a more favorable position to cultivate enthusiasm and dynamism. This year of Fire. The suggestion is to return to the Classic of Changes (易经Yì jīng), to try to understand what the Fire hexagram has to offer, which is adherent and brilliant, composed of two trigrams of Fire (离下、离上 Lí Xià, Li Shàng), therefore the representation of the element in a pure state, thus enabling the understanding of the fundamental characteristics of the Fire Horse that enters in the middle of February. In Richard Wilhelm's interpretation, translated into English by Cary F. Baynes (1989, 118-121), we read that fire is dependent, it is always conditioned to something or someone else, for example to the combustion of Wood, only in this way can it be so alive and bright, and the more it burns, the more it rises from the earth towards the sky. In the judgment of the lines it is informed that if you adhere with perseverance like a cow, you will be guaranteed success (離，利貞，亨。畜牝牛，吉。2) (Zhang, 1995,131). Regarding his image, he appears to illuminate and doubly so, since when he shines he does so for himself and for others (《象》明兩作，離；大人以繼明，照於四方) (Zhang, 1995,135)., just as the sun shines and warms the earth throughout the day. Being a conditioned element, like all others, in a world of interdependence, everything that does not burn positively and for good must be abandoned, just like the ancient Chinese leaders at the end of the dynasties who stopped being model and became capricious and destructive. The positive energy of the Fire Horse is like a beneficent sun that inspires everyone. If you ask the greatest of all Chinese poets, Li Bai (701-762), here in the translation by António Graça de Abreu, in One Hundred Poems of Li Bai 李白诗一百首 what virtues he associates with the horse, we read in response, for example, in “Your bay horse 君马黄” which is friendship and life experience, with its highs and low, but always worthy of being lived in the company of good friends: 君马黄，我马白。 马色虽不同，人心本无隔。 共作游治盘，双行洛阳陌。 长剑既照曜，高冠何赤3赫。 各有千金裘，俱为五侯客。 猛虎落陷阱，壮士时屈厄。 Article Your horse is bay my horse is white. Different color of horses, similar to the hearts of friends. Through the streets of Luoyang we know happy days, sword at waist, tall hats, valuable fur coats. guests of five marquises. Even tigers fall into the trap. Today strong and brave, Tomorrow subject to the misadventures of luck. If such a day happens, Help from a friend. (Abreu, 2021, 174) In a leap forward to contemporary times, we will find in the poet Yao Feng (1958-), in Palavras Cansadas da Gramática (2014), the same traditional reading and an interesting identification with the horse, in “Cavalo Velho”, preserving the idea of friendship that extends throughout the Chinese centuries, but in an inverted presentation of the free condition of the animal, which appears, as happens mutatis mutandis to so many people, sad and imprisoned, unnaturally, in a cart, that is, a social condition, translated into the provision of services to others: Accustomed to the coachman, to passers-by, to cars Forgotten what it's like to gallop Dirty, sagging skin, gloomy as the end of the day Ironed hulls make the trail on the flat Even longer Sitting in a noisy village tavern I saw a horse bent under the weight of the cart Pull up and I would like To tell him in his language: Come in here, old friend, I'll buy you a drink! (Yao, 2014, 122) It is certainly against the essential nature of equids to allow themselves to be imprisoned. They, who love to run freely across the prairies and steppes, through the mountains and valleys, can be domesticated by friendship, suffering and participating in the place of the social order that humans have destined for them. And like people, they also age, losing much of the vigor and energy they were born with, which is reflected in skin that loses its shine and sags. But while they are in the strength of life, and if they are lucky enough to remain free, there is no greater dynamism than theirs. To conclude, my poetic tribute to the Year of the Horse that gallops towards us brimming with strength, enthusiasm and joy: Fire Horse Beautiful, fast, dreamy, Run against the pain, Growing in wind or breeze in the wake of flowers, They dancing in the passage, paws loaded with earth and heat. Beautiful, fast, dreamy, carry the monkey, And on the back the dragon, they call it the Spirit of the Dragon Horse. 龙马精神 Horse-Dragon Spirit, In a year that brings shine and the light like heralds, sounding strong and loud. item.title: Today Macau
item.description: Several countries and regions in Asia reacted Saturday to the US Supreme Court's decision that annulled the tariffs imposed by the President, as well as the new 10 percent global tax that Donald Trump instituted after the court decision. Tokyo rules out that the invalidation of the rates will affect previously agreed investments, according to the economic newspaper Nikkei, while Taiwan and Hong Kong foresee a “limited” effect of the new global tariff. China has not yet commented. In response to the resolution, which invalidates the so-called “reciprocal tariffs” and other generalized taxes applied by Trump, with a minimum rate of 10 percent, the President signed a global tariff of 10 percent on all countries. The law that supports this new executive order only allows tariffs to be increased by up to 15 percent and for periods of 150 days, so it is not clear how it will be articulated in the long term, writes the EFE news agency. South Korea said the trade deal with Washington, which provides for commitments such as a $350 billion South Korean investment and 15 percent tariffs from Washington, remains intact. According to Yonhap news agency, South Korean authorities called an emergency meeting to assess the impact of invalidating the tariffs. The governments of Taiwan and Hong Kong consider that the 10 percent global tariff announced by Trump will have a “limited impact” on their economies. Indonesia, which on Thursday signed a trade agreement with the US, indicated that it will hold “new talks” with Washington in light of the “dynamics that are occurring”. Malaysia assured that it “will continue to diversify its trade relations and strengthen regional and multilateral economic cooperation”, despite the decision that invalidates a large part of Trump's tariffs.

item.title: Diaspora | Greater connection between Casa de Macau and Casa de Goa defended
item.description: The conference “Casa de Goa and Casa de Macau: fundamental agents of an indispensable dialogue” took place in Lisbon yesterday, which analyzed the connecting role that the entities can have in the Goan and Macau diaspora. Carlos Piteira, president of Casa de Macau, highlights the importance of creating bridges with Casa de Goa through the “parallel representation of Portuguese descendants” What role can Casa de Macau and Casa de Goa, in Lisbon, have, taking into account the passage of time and the developments brought by the new generations of the Macanese and Goan communities? It is true that Macau and Goa have long ceased to be part of the former Portuguese empire, but sociocultural ties remain. With this in mind, the lecture “Casa de Goa and Casa de Macau: fundamental agents of an indispensable dialogue” took place yesterday at the Lisbon Geography Society, which sought to outline answers to the challenges of the future. To HM, Carlos Piteira, president of the Casa de Macau in Lisbon, declared that “it would be interesting if the bridges between the Casa de Macau and the Casa de Goa could also be considered in parallel with their representation of Portuguese descendants and mixed cultures”, taking into account that the two entities “are fundamental pillars for the representation of these communities”. The person responsible, himself Macanese, highlights “the similarities of their gastronomy, Creole and festivities” between the two communities. It would therefore be “interesting to combine the small representations of the giants of the Asian world, represented by the symbolism of the Dragon and the Elephant, as structuring elements for a dialogue between Portugal and Asia, political and institutional wills permit”. In Carlos Piteira's view, the two houses “reinforce the legitimized heritage of the dialogue between the West and the East, and Portugal's centuries-old relations with these countries, often ignored and forgotten by official and institutional powers”. Pedro Colaço, from the management of Casa de Goa, highlights the importance of preserving the memory of the Portuguese presence both in Goa and in the remaining territories of Daman and Diu. "There have been 450 years of history, in the case of Macau it was a few more decades, and we try to keep up with current Goan culture. One of the most important parts of our work is to build a bridge between Goa and Lisbon, and on a daily basis we contact artists, musicians and members of the community, that is our role", he described to HM. Pedro Colaço gave the example of the concert that will take place on March 8th at Fundação Oriente, in Lisbon, entitled “Oscar Castellino – Voz de Ópera de Goa and Piano with Rodrigo Ayala”. De resto, a Casa de Goa, actualmente sem sede própria, procura, tal como a Casa de Macau, atrair novos sócios, sobretudo das novas gerações, a fim de dar continuidade ao projecto, para que a Casa se mantenha “como um polo de união dos goeses e, cada vez mais, dos amigos de Goa”. Acompanhar a história A Casa de Macau foi fundada em Lisboa em 1966 e tem acompanhado diversas fases não só da história de Portugal como do relacionamento do país com Macau e a China. "The existence of the House of Macau undoubtedly marks a parallel with the history of Portugal itself for more than 70 years. Macau was the 'pearl of the East' for the Estado Novo and lived through the turmoil of the revolutionary period of April 1974, adapting and establishing itself as the 'bridge between the West and East'". Finally, after the transition to the People's Republic of China, we have seen the reorganization [of Macau] as a central territory in the connection, from China, with Portuguese-speaking countries.” Carlos Piteira also described that the House of Macau has followed “the history of the times, expanding the vision of the Portuguese presence in this territory”. Furthermore, he had a “no less important” task, having “crystallized, protected and perpetuated the Macanese community in Portugal and the world”. Currently, Casa de Macau has developed several activities that bring more members to Avenida Gago Coutinho, where it is located, and whose building has recently undergone restoration work. Every Wednesday there are Macanese food lunches with Chef Tina, originally from Macau, as well as film sessions and lectures. The Casa's mission is currently “to carry out activities to promote Macau and Macanese culture”, providing “support and promotion of studies and works of scientific content about Macau, Macau people” and also providing “institutional interconnection with other entities linked to Macau, Portugal and Casas de Macau in the diaspora”. Who is from Goa and who is not Pedro Colaço explained that the Goan community in Lisbon “has an easier time talking to the remaining Indian diaspora” in Portugal, taking into account that, for example, “the connection is very old” with the Hindu community. “We are sorry that sometimes [the community] is not talked about more in the media, because it is an important part of Portuguese history”, laments the person in charge, remembering prominent figures in the country, such as António Costa, who was Portuguese prime minister, or Narana Coissoró, former president of Casa de Goa and former deputy of the CDS-PP. “There are more notorious figures, but in general the Goan community has integrated itself very well and is known for being a very educated community”, he also recalled, regretting that in Portugal it is not possible to make a distinction between communities of Indian origin. "One thing that is worrying is the lack of knowledge that exists in relation to the communities. Nowadays there is a lot of pressure due to immigration and then everything gets mixed up", highlights Pedro Colaço, remembering that there is a strong feeling in being Goan, particularly in connection with Catholicism and a very unique culture as opposed to Hindustani communities that are currently very present in Portugal. "The Goan community is so mixed that half of my family, or more, do not appear to be Goan, but I, by chance, do. There is a feeling of being Goan, something that unites us. The other communities of the Indian diaspora are often confessional, they have an associated religion, while the Goan community is, for the most part, Catholic, but everyone goes to their own church, it is very spread out", he pointed out. The future is a challenge Pedro Colaço speaks of a “challenging future” for Casa de Goa. "I'm now in my second term, the leadership has changed president, and one of the things we've been trying to do is to bring young people into the governing bodies. We now have three or four younger members, under the age of 40. We've also been trying to expand the House to non-Goans." In this point, there are similarities with the Casa de Macau, which has also sought to expand the range of members to Chinese or Portuguese people who do not belong to the community. Pedro Colaço adds that, over the years, things have changed. "30 years ago the community was very large, but at this moment, and like all institutions, we have to expand. There are many people who really like Goa and who know a lot about the territory, perhaps even more than me, and they are the ones who have to be pulled", he assumed. Currently, Casa de Goa has 500 members and, even without a headquarters, it seeks to carry out activities, particularly in partnership with Fundação Oriente. A monthly bulletin is published. They no longer have headquarters due to the metro works in Lisbon, which has made the House's agenda difficult. “We are in the process of finding a new headquarters, and it is something that has been a constraint, but we try to carry out as many activities as possible and, every month, we always have activities”, concluded Pedro Colaço.

item.title: Macau Lawyers Association declares support for the State Security Defense Commission law
item.description: The Macau Lawyers Association, chaired by former deputy Vong Hin Fai, considers the requirements required by the proposed law that will regulate the State Security Defense Commission to be reasonable and necessary. In an opinion article signed by the association, published in the newspaper Ou Mun, the veto on the participation of lawyers in any process considered in any way related to national security is defended. In the text, the association argues that many countries and regions have similar laws, pointing to the examples of the Special Advocate Statute in the United Kingdom and Canada, the classified information procedures law in the United States of America and the regulation of legal practitioners in Hong Kong. All the regimes mentioned by AAM are based on legal systems of the Common Law style, the British tradition, which contrasts with the reality of Macau, which adopts a legal system of the so-called continental tradition, with roots in Germany and France and which also applies to Portugal. Full support The association also said that it agrees and supports the proposed law, as it considers that it advances and improves the commission's duties and competencies while “fully applying the general perspective of national security”. The association also cites the justification note to emphasize that “the defense of State security constitutes a constitutional responsibility of the Macao SAR”. The Macau Lawyers Association also highlighted that Macau must “implement the decisions and instructions of the Central Government within the scope of national security” and that this proposed law, by strengthening the powers of the commission, will maintain “coherence with the norms of the Hong Kong national security law” and “coordinate with the Electoral Law for the Chief Executive and the Electoral Law for the Legislative Assembly”.

item.title: Security | Macao SAR rulers applaud White Paper on Hong Kong
item.description: China has released a new White Paper on national security, on Hong Kong, which is entitled “Practice of Safeguarding National Security in Hong Kong under ‘One Country, Two Systems.’ In the Macao SAR, secretaries and political leaders reacted positively, saying that the document provides guarantees of stability and is a reference for Macau Days after the conviction in Hong Kong of Jimmy Lai, a media entrepreneur who founded the now-defunct Apple Daily newspaper, China launches a new White Paper focused on the need to safeguard national security in neighboring territory. The “Practice of Safeguarding National Security in Hong Kong under ‘One Country, Two Systems'” was published by the Communication Department of China's State Council on Tuesday. According to the Xinhua news agency, this White Paper consists of five parts, detailing “the persistent struggle to safeguard national security in Hong Kong and the fundamental responsibility of the Central Government in national security matters related to Hong Kong”. In the same note, it is explained that the White Paper “exposes the achievements of the HKSAR in fulfilling its constitutional responsibility to safeguard national security” and also “Hong Kong’s transition from chaos to stability and prosperity”. “Efforts to create [a security landscape] of high standard are not forgotten in order to promote the high-quality development of the ‘One Country, Two Systems' policy”, in addition to being explained that “the Central Government applied a holistic approach to national security”. In this context, “it effectively exercised general jurisdiction over the HKSAR, in accordance with the country's Constitution and the Basic Law of the HKSAR”, and the Law on Safeguarding National Security “has been applied in the region” and has ensured “that Hong Kong is administered by patriots”. On the Macao SAR side, the government apparatus reacted positively to this White Paper, after the bill that presents a new format and composition of the Macao SAR State Security Defense Commission, created in 2018, was generally approved in the Legislative Assembly. Chan Tsz King, Secretary for Security, was one of the political figures who reacted to the document, which considers “ensuring the stable and lasting implementation” of the “One Country, Two Systems” principle. Quoted in an official note, the secretary understands that the White Paper comes to “clarify the intrinsic unity between political principles and institutional logic, causing Hong Kong society to return to normality and order to be restored”. The document, in the secretary's view, “serves as an important reference for the Macao SAR to review and improve the construction of its legal system in the context of defending the security of the State and the respective execution mechanism”. Chan Tsz King highlights that his leadership will give “great importance to ensuring security in non-traditional areas under the new situation, establishing the long-term stability of the Macao SAR as a strategic objective”. Firm as a rock Also according to Xinhua, the White Paper describes how Beijing “supports the HKSAR in fulfilling its constitutional responsibility to safeguard national security by effectively preventing, interrupting and punishing any activities that put national security at risk”. “The efforts” of the neighboring region to safeguard national security aim, according to the same document, to “sustain and develop” the principle created by Beijing to support Taiwan and the two special administrative regions, without forgetting the protection of “fundamental human rights, dignity and well-being of the 7.5 million residents of Hong Kong”. The White Paper released by the State Council also states that “in today's world, and with unprecedented global transformations that have occurred in a century, they are accelerating, with the development environment facing China undergoing profound and complex changes”. In this way, “safeguarding national security is a long-term and permanent task”, it is said. The White Paper states that Hong Kong “enjoys a high standard of security”, with the region “fated to overcome all risks and challenges in the future journey, remaining as stable as a rock in a turbulent world”. Another political figure from the Macao SAR who reacted was Adriano Marques Ho, director-general of the Customs Service, saying that the White Paper “has an important guiding significance and a profound impact for the complete and accurate implementation of ‘One Country, Two Systems’ in the Hong Kong and Macau regions, for the realization of long-term prosperity and stability, and for their stable and sustainable progression”. Adriano Marques Ho added that “both Hong Kong and Macau are inalienable and sacred parts of China”, and Beijing “has firmly and consistently maintained national sovereignty, security and development interests”. In the view of the top Customs official, “the external hostile forces and anti-China elements disturbing Hong Kong incited and created the ‘legislative review riots’, which ended up evolving into a ‘color revolution’ version of Hong Kong, seriously damaging the constitutional order and the rule of law in Hong Kong, and putting national sovereignty, security and development interests at risk”. End of the “chaotic situation” Lam, Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, said the White Paper “comprehensively analyzes and outlines Hong Kong's journey in defending national security, major achievements and experience gained”. In the governor's view, “Hong Kong went from a chaotic situation to stability and prosperity”. In the case of Macau, the principles contained in the White Paper apply, with the secretary promising to “continue to intensify education, giving priority to the formation of a social base that supports the values ​​of love for the country and for Macau”. In this context, the aim is to “develop a comprehensive educational system to increase the patriotic feeling of young people and consolidate the ideological foundation of national security through multidimensional educational activities and exchanges”. It is promised that the Social Affairs and Culture department “will continue to promote national security using culture as a driving force, reinforcing the exploration and dissemination of Macau’s historical and cultural resources and organizing different types of exhibitions and cultural shows with unique characteristics”. The idea is to “spread the excellent Chinese cultural heritage in order to resist the erosion of harmful cultures, reinforce the cultural and national identity of the population and unite the forces of different sectors of society through culture”. Wong Sio Chak, Secretary for Administration and Justice, who for years held the Security portfolio, considers that the White Paper has “extreme relevance for Macao SAR issues relating to the defense of national security”, particularly with regard to “defending sovereignty, security and the development interests of the State”. The promises are that the area of ​​Administration and Justice “will boost legislative production in the priority areas related to the defense of State security, continuing to improve the respective legal regime”, with “training courses on the Constitution, the Basic Law and legislation relating to the defense of State security aimed at public service workers at different levels”. In turn, Tai Kin Ip, Secretary for Economy and Finance, described that “economic and financial security constitute non-traditional key domains among the twenty priority areas of the global vision of national security, and are also crucial factors in ensuring the stable development and long-term security of Macau and the country”. Tai Kin Ip aims to “pragmatically promote the development of adequate diversification of the economy, strengthening Macau’s global economic resilience and maintaining a high level of attention to various risks and challenges in the economic and financial domain”. Raymond Tam, Secretary for Transport and Public Works, said Macau must “cultivate an awareness of vigilance in times of peace, in order to consolidate the foundations of lasting stability and security”. In this sense, the government official understands that “Macau must always put the safeguarding of the sovereignty, security and development interests of the State first”, and in terms of Transport and Public Works he promises to “persist in the predominance of Executive power, firmly integrating the safeguarding of national security in all tasks”. Ao Ieong Seong, Commissioner against Corruption, believes that “the security and stability of the political environment and the good functioning of the system, with the predominance of the Executive branch, [guarantees that] the level of governance in the Macao SAR is increasingly higher”. The commissioner highlighted “last year’s successful holding of the elections for the 8th Legislative Assembly, reinforcing the implementation of the principle of ‘Macau governed by patriots’ and effectively ensuring the lasting stability of the Macao SAR”.

item.title: Heritage | Stories of the stores on Rua Cinco de Outubro told in a book
item.description: Natalie Fu has just released a book about traditional commerce on Rua Cinco de Outubro, at the invitation of the Macau Cultural Heritage Reinvention Studies Association. “Macao’s Historical House Taxonomy – The Shophouses at the Rua Cinco de Outubro” tells the centuries-old story of shophouses that were the “heart of Macau’s Chinese community” A book has just been published that reveals a little about the history of commerce carried out by the Chinese community on Rua Cinco de Outubro, located in Porto Interior, the scene of many commercial movements over the centuries. The work also explains how these stores, which are at the same time houses, reveal details about the history of Macau. “Macao’s Historical House Taxonomy – The Shophouses at the Rua Cinco de Outubro”, written by Natalie Fu, a doctoral student at the University of São José, was invited by the Association for Studies on the Reinvention of Cultural Heritage of Macau, whose edition also depends on “the support and assistance of many other people”, the author told HM. One of the book's sales outlets, which does not have a Portuguese version, is Pin-to Livros. “The investigation began with the love for Macau and its old buildings”, reveals the author, who began the research work around these buildings in 2022, in the middle of the pandemic. "Rua de Cinco de Outubro has always been an important commercial area in Macau. Once, it was the heart of Macau's Chinese community. Even today, many old stores remain close to the local neighborhood. The stores are mixed-use buildings", explains the author. This is the stage for commercial diversity, as Rua Cinco de Outubro “is home to several businesses, such as traditional Chinese bakeries, Chinese medicine stores, tea shops and fruit shops”. According to the presentation of the work, made on social media by the association itself, this type of property constitutes “a common type of multifunctional residential building”, where the “plan of the buildings is generally rectangular, with two to three floors”. Typically, the ground floor is used for the store or as a warehouse, while the upper floors are reserved for housing. "This type of construction can adapt to the local climate, presenting great flexibility in the construction methods and materials used. Due to the diversity of daily uses, shop houses were once the main type of building on the streets of Macau, having important historical, social, cultural, architectural and aesthetic value", it further reads. Preservation Challenges Still according to the same note, the book draws attention to the importance of preserving this type of construction and, consequently, a symbol of local heritage. “Unfortunately, because they are small-scale and scattered buildings, and because they are not fully protected by the Macau Heritage Protection Law, they have been gradually disappearing with the rapid development of society”, and, currently, “only a small number of these buildings have the classification of ‘monument’ and are protected”. For Natalie Fu, “the preservation of Macau's stores faces many challenges, one of which is the fact that they are not included in the existing list of protected old buildings in Macau”, in addition to that, in her view, “changes in construction laws have also made it difficult to maintain these old buildings”. Asked about the future of this iconic street in Porto Interior, the author recognizes that “the growth of a city inevitably involves the renovation and disappearance of buildings”, so “determining which buildings should be preserved and how to preserve them is a long-term challenge”. Natalie Fu even talks about the need to extend the investigation to more streets in Macau that are also traditional shopping areas. "Research and documentation of the stores on Rua Cinco de Outubro and in Macau are urgent as their number is dwindling. Additionally, additional academic investigations and discussions with the local community are needed to inform the future direction of the Inner Harbor area." In relation to the panorama on Rua Cinco de Outubro, the author describes that maintenance should be focused on, keeping commercial spaces open. "Stores that are kept in use better highlight their social value. Taking some stores on Rua Cinco de Outubro as an example, the existence of century-old stores further emphasizes the cultural and historical value of the area and the stores. Furthermore, 'keeping them in use' allows for more immediate monitoring and maintenance, which is the most direct way of protecting ancient architecture." A certain influence In a territory characterized by the coexistence of Portuguese and Chinese cultures, Natalie Fu's book shows how these houses were influenced by other cultures. “Chinese and Western architecture in Macau have always influenced each other throughout historical development, and this feature is particularly visible in the appearance of the shop houses.” In this way, this book helps to cement this characteristic, “establishing a classification system for Macau’s shop houses, consolidating their architectural definition”. This book is, therefore, a “classifying study of the old shop houses in Macau”, constituting “the first step towards their safeguarding”, describes, in the same note, the association that supported the editorial and research project. "The author carried out a detailed record and survey [of the stores], starting with visits and cartography surveys in the Porto Interior area. Maps were drawn up of the location of the shop houses on that street, analysis sheets based on fieldwork, photographic records and interviews with current traders and residents, in order to understand the history of the use of each building." Furthermore, the work documents seven cases in particular, “providing information on their history, evolution and current use, as well as a preliminary discussion on possible preservation directions”. The book also records two examples of shop houses that have now disappeared. “It is hoped that this work will encourage more people to discover the ‘beauty of Macau.’ With the shop houses as a central theme, it is expected to promote exchange and discussion between academics from different areas”, the association also points out. Natalie Fu invited “several experts and academics to share their ideas, experiences and suggestions on the protection and future of this type of buildings”, it is described. Born and raised in Macau, Natalie Fu had the opportunity to visit all of Southeast Asia from a young age, trips that led her to “foster a deep appreciation and passion for architecture”. The author has a degree in Architecture, also describing herself as a person interested in the area of ​​heritage conservation and a “historical architecture scholar trained in Macau”.

item.title: Security Committee | Jurists warn of contradiction to the Basic Law
item.description: Despite support for national security issues, the requirements of the State Security Defense Commission's proposed law are considered contrary and incomprehensible in light of Macau's legal framework Analysts interviewed by Lusa consider the proposed law for the Commission for the Defense of State Security, voted yesterday in the Legislative Assembly, to be unconstitutional, highlighting “disturbing aspects”, such as restrictions on the appointment of lawyers in national security cases. The proposed law that will frame the State Security Defense Commission (CDSE) was discussed and voted on in general by deputies to the Legislative Assembly yesterday. The document, according to Macau-based lawyer Luís Almeida Pinto, “contains disturbing aspects of the constitutional functioning of various powers, and also in some matters of rights, freedoms and guarantees enshrined in the Macau ‘Constitution’: the Basic Law”. Anticipating changes to the Basic Law of the Judicial Organization, the proposal determines that the choice of a lawyer for national security cases is subject to the approval of a judge, who forwards the request to the CDSE, so that it can issue a binding and non-appealable opinion. Special authorization, the Government proposes, can occur in criminal or other proceedings, when “there are well-founded reasons to believe that there is a need to protect the interests of State security”. Almeida Pinto evokes the Basic Law, which guarantees “access to the Law, the courts, and assistance from a lawyer in the defense of their legitimate rights and interests”, to point out that it is up to the defendant “to freely choose the lawyer who best serves him”. “It seems like a rule that will be unconstitutional when approved, and when applied in practice”, he explains. Collision with Lawyer's Statute In addition to being “a violation of the Basic Law”, with constitutional force in Macau, Pedro Leal, who has practiced law in the territory for several decades, points out “clearly, a collision” between what is proposed and “the decree that regulates the Lawyers Association and the Statute” of the Lawyer, with regard to the free choice of a defender. This is the “most debatable issue” of the proposal, assumes Leal, who says he agrees with the legislative initiative. "China pays special attention to security issues, it is a world power, as such it does not want interference in any way. I understand the position and I understand that it does not want changes to the 'status quo'. (…) Now, they want to do things, do them well", he adds. Speaking to Lusa, Almeida Pinto also considers the regime envisaged to be “unacceptable” for “inquiries to be made to lawyers” who wish to legally represent a defendant in national security cases. Attached to the request made by the agents to the judge, there must be, among other elements, information regarding the members of the lawyer's household, nationality and connection with organizations or individuals abroad. This is a “real investigation into personal life”, when “what is only at stake is the exercise of the profession for which he is duly registered and authorized by the Macau Lawyers Association”, he says. The requirement, “in addition to being extremely vague, is perfectly impossible” to implement, assesses Leal, who suggests “it is implicit” that a non-Chinese lawyer will not be authorized representation in these cases – it should be noted that in cases of national security, only the intervention of Chinese judges is now permitted. Question of times Another doubt, raised to Lusa by jurist António Katchi, concerns the time it will take for the CDSE to issue the opinion. The proposal does not clarify this aspect, so the Code of Administrative Procedure “should” be applied, which sets the deadline for acts to be carried out by administrative bodies at 15 days. But, says Katchi, “will the CDSE follow this same understanding or will it consider (without the possibility of this being denied by any court) that it can simply leave the issue to its next semi-annual ordinary meeting?”. If the opinion is negative and it is necessary to repeat the process, with a new legal representative, “how many months or years will the defendant remain deprived of his liberty, without a lawyer”? Alluding to the principle of judicial independence, which he recalls is guaranteed by the Basic Law, António Katchi deduces “with complete certainty, the inadmissibility of subjecting a judicial decision to a binding opinion from an administrative body, namely the CDSE”. The professor also talks about the importance of a relationship of trust between constituent and lawyer and “how vital it is, for a person at risk of a prison sentence, to be defended by a lawyer who is sincerely motivated by the cause and well versed in the matter involved”. In addition to the Basic Law and the Joint Declaration, signed by Lisbon and Beijing in 1987, and which defined rules for Macau after the transition of administration, Katchi highlights another legal provision that the proposal contradicts: the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), according to which, he quotes, “every person accused of a crime shall have the right, in full equality, (…) to present himself at trial and to defend himself in person or to be assisted by a defender of your choice.” The ICCPR is one of the instruments that constitute the UN International Bill of Human Rights. In 1992, when Macau was still a territory administered by Portugal, Lisbon extended this convention to the region. Although China signed the treaty in 1998, it never ratified it, and is not bound by its rules. The Basic Law, explains António Katchi, points out that restrictions on fundamental rights, including the right to be assisted by a lawyer, “cannot contradict the provisions of the ICCPR”.

item.title: Cooperation | Relations between China and Timor-Leste guided by caution, study indicates
item.description: It is certain that, by being part of the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, Timor-Leste can become a strategic point in commercial relations on this side of the globe, despite the “cautious pragmatism” in relations with China. The conclusion is from a study on Timorese foreign policy within the scope of the Chinese initiative, authored by three Portuguese academics Timor-Leste, a young country, has been cementing its relations with China, namely through the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, but there is still some caution surrounding this relationship. This is one of the conclusions of the study “Timor-Leste's foreign policy options within the scope of China's Belt and Road 2.0 Initiative: a small state perspective”, authored by academics Tiago Botelho dos Santos, Diogo Borges and Paulo Afonso Duarte. The work was published in The Pacific Review, an academic journal edited by Taylor & Francis. The research work starts with Timor-Leste's adherence to the Chinese initiative, something that happened in 2017, to analyze how the relationship with China has been going, taking into account the fact that Timor-Leste has “the status of a small state”. It is concluded, therefore, that “Timor-Leste's involvement with China's Belt and Road Initiative, particularly in the post-2023 period, can be understood as a strategic and calculated attempt to maximize its status as a small state in a complex regional and global environment”. It is described that, in this period, Timorese foreign policy has been characterized “by a multi-vector approach, strategically anchored in multilateralism”, seeking to “diversify international partnerships to reinforce national security, promote economic development and expand its voice in the international system”. The study points out that relations between Timor-Leste and China, in the context of the Belt and Road initiative, are a “deliberate movement to leverage development opportunities” in the country, being a strategy aligned with the Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan 2011-2030. The plan aims to “promote economic diversification and the development of critical infrastructure, in a context in which the Belt and Road 2.0 Initiative emphasizes digital infrastructure, green energy and cooperation in the area of ​​health”.
