Timorese potential The three academics also highlight that Timor-Leste, as part of the Chinese geopolitical initiative, has the potential to stand out economically, and also in commercial terms, in the region. The country has “the potential to assert itself as a logistical center on a route that connects the South Indian Ocean to the South Pacific”, so the Chinese initiative “offers a relevant opportunity to significantly increase its regional prominence and decisively facilitate” integration into ASEAN [Association of Southeast Asian Nations], to which Timor-Leste recently joined. Despite all these positive signs, the study concludes that “although Timor-Leste's relationship with China has deepened, culminating in a comprehensive strategic partnership in 2024, its engagement continues to be marked by cautious pragmatism”. In this context, “the benefits of greater connectivity and investment are carefully weighed against concerns regarding debt sustainability, transparency and possible strategic dependencies”. This caution on the part of Timor-Leste demonstrates its “capacity for action by selectively engaging in projects aligned with its national interests”, navigating the “complexities of competition between great powers in the Indo-Pacific, while maintaining its commitment to a balanced and diversified foreign policy”. Timorese pragmatism is also evident, according to the study, in the fact that the country “not only optimizes development opportunities, but also reinforces its regional position by meticulously analyzing economic benefits in the face of potential risks”. What is strengthened, “ultimately”, is the “capacity for action as a small State”, highlight the authors. A “remarkable” ability The study in question highlights how Timor-Leste has had “a remarkable capacity for action” in the context of the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, using other small States, such as Sri Lanka, as a point of comparison. Citing other studies, the three academics highlight how “Timor-Leste has demonstrated a more cautious approach than countries like Sri Lanka, which have faced significant concerns about debt sustainability associated with BRI [Belt and Road Initiative] projects, or landlocked states like Laos and coastal nations like Cambodia.” In the case of these Southeast Asian countries, “Chinese loans for emblematic projects, such as railways and highways, have drastically increased external debt and dependence on Beijing”. What we sought to do in this investigation was “to examine the unique position of Timor-Leste, not as a financier, but also not as a victim of a ‘debt trap'”, highlighting “the distinct and valuable form of action capacity of a small State within the scope of the BRI”. The authors highlight that, in the last decade, China “significantly expanded its presence in Southeast Asia” through the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, thereby “expanding its regional influence in the economic, security and political spheres”. In this relationship, Timor-Leste has been “far from being a passive observer”, seeking to “actively engage with China to ensure development benefits”. Timor-Leste sought to “identify an opportunity to align with the long-term objectives” of its 2011-2030 Strategic Development Plan, analysts indicate. “Strategically, the country also intends to capitalize on its geographic position in emerging commercial maritime routes, particularly through the establishment of a logistics hub in the South Indian Ocean and the South Pacific, potentially reinforcing its regional role as a new integrated member state of ASEAN”, point out the authors. Timor-Leste seeks to “balance economic gains and potential dependencies”, in a geopolitical context that “includes competition between great powers in the Indo-Pacific, where United States policies, under successive administrations, aim to contain China's regional influence”. In methodological terms, the authors carried out this investigation based on reading official reports, documents that serve as the basis for signed bilateral agreements and government documentation. In addition, interviews were carried out with “experts based in both Europe and Asia”. The authors state that they sought to interview academics and diplomats “due to the fact that ordinary citizens are generally unfamiliar with China's global multilateral initiatives, while diplomats tend to be excessively cautious in their statements, as they represent the official position of their state, and not necessarily their personal opinions”. It is therefore understood that academics “tend to offer more balanced and rigorous analyses”. The questions focused on how Timor-Leste, as a small State, has benefited from the Chinese initiative, whether this initiative is compatible with the Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan 2011-2030, or whether “there are visible dangers of creating dependency” between the two countries, among other issues.

item.title: USJ | Book highlights panorama of philanthropy in Macau
item.description: The book “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures” has just been published by the University of São José. One of the chapters deals with philanthropy in Macau, the discreet profile of philanthropists and the work of entities such as Fundação Rui Cunha, Banco Nacional Ultramarino and Fundação Oriente The University of São José (USJ) has just published the book “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures”, edited by professor José Manuel Simões. As the name indicates, the work aims to outline the panorama of arts, media and culture in the nine Portuguese-speaking countries and regions, which includes Macau. Macao SAR is represented with a chapter dedicated to philanthropy, written by Carmen Zita Monereo, post-doctoral student at USJ, entitled “The Impact of Corporate Philanthropy on Media, Art, and Technology in Macao / What do we know about Philanthropy in Macao? What is the relationship between Confucianism, Philanthropy, Media, and strategic communication?”. “Carmen has been developing a study on philanthropy in Macau, which is a slightly different work than the rest”, she began by telling HM José Manuel Simões. "This is a work that contributes to the analysis of the spectrum of philanthropists in Macau, then outlining a study on the Rui Cunha Foundation, Banco Nacional Ultramarino, Fundação Oriente. It looks at what corporate philanthropy is and the impacts it has on society through an analysis of the media, but also art and technology in Macau. In other words, it questions what we know about philanthropy in Macau and what is the relationship between Confucianism, philanthropy, the media and strategic communication.” José Manuel Simões adds that one of the innovative points in this chapter is the discreet profile of philanthropists. “A curious aspect is that, unlike philanthropists from Europe and the United States, who really like to appear in rankings, in Macau there is greater discretion and a low profile of these people linked to philanthropy, and this has to do with the culture itself.” The editor of the work adds that “in the field of communication sciences [in Macau] philanthropy has gained great importance as a communication instrument”, and that Carmen Zita Monereo’s work “identifies the values ​​of an organizational culture that is capable of generating communication flows conducive to innovation through this philanthropic activity”. The book, which is available for free in digital version, “seeks to draw links between various vectors, and one of them is the nine Portuguese-speaking cultures”, without forgetting Macau “as a connection platform between China and Portuguese-speaking countries”. According to José Manuel Simões, it is a book “whose research was developed seeking to adopt a multidisciplinary approach”, having “an academic nature, but, at the same time, it aims to have a simple and accessible language”. Cape Verde’s good example With a bilingual edition, the book presents “a very broad spectrum” of themes, containing an article by José Manuel Simões on São Tomé and Príncipe, entitled “Digital Media Contribution to Entrepreneurship and Development in São Tomé and Príncipe”. Below is an article on the educational panorama in Angola and the use of artificial intelligence (AI), written by Wilson Gomes Caldeira, entitled “Angola’s higher education system: An analysis of the opportunities and challenges presented by Artificial Intelligence”. In the case of Cape Verde, Silvino Lopes Évora explores the ideas of social communication in conjunction with AI, in “Artificial Intelligence, newsroom culture, and journalism: From international spectrum to experiences in Cape Verde”. “Cape Verde is a good example of media development in Africa and Silvino Évora's text works on the AI ​​component in the media and how it is being inserted. [The text also analyzes] what are the possibilities for using AI and how ethics can monitor and support AI and, at the same time, journalism”, adds José Manuel Simões. The book published by USJ also explores, in the chapter “The media system as a leverage for democratic development in East Timor”, by Paulo Faustino and Rui Alexandre Novais, the links between journalism and the historical memories of the independence process. The book's editor explains the “more historical component regarding the role of remission that journalists still have today to almost preserve the memory of those who died in favor of the country's independence”. "Journalism is of enormous importance in Timor, there were people and journalists who died. This is very little talked about and in this study there is an interesting conclusion, that these people, when they died in the name of freedom of expression, left a very important place in Timor-Leste that is still in force today, seeking to preserve their memory through surveillance over other powers." In this way, “Timor-Leste is almost an example of how journalism should act as a watchdog of other powers, which does not happen in other sectors”. José Manuel Simões highlights the case of Guinea-Bissau, “where journalists are called hired mouths”. "They don't know the difference between advertising, public relations, marketing and journalism, because they are conditioned by a very low salary. They write what they ask for in exchange for an envelope with some money inside, and this makes the profession [of journalism] very fragile in Guinea Bissau", he stressed. A language of unity According to José Manuel Simões, the book aims to unite “these quadrants of Portuguese cultures”, and the English edition aims to reach Anglo-Saxon communities, “so that they know about the existence of these cultures”. "There are those who do not agree with me regarding the idea that the Portuguese language is a language of unity, not only among Portuguese-speaking peoples, but even within each country. We have the case of Timor-Leste, which on the island of Ataúro alone, which is very small, with 500 thousand inhabitants, has 40 dialects, one in each village. There, what does the Portuguese language do? It unites these people, because despite there being a difference between the who speak and those who learned Portuguese, in Timor-Leste, today, the elderly speak Portuguese and young people too, but there is the age group that goes from 25 to 50, who do not speak it. But, because it is a language of learning, because it is official, because it has books, a memory, Portuguese unites all these ethnicities and dialects, and has a common value, because the Portuguese language is everyone's mother tongue”, he explains. José Manuel Simões does not forget the work that CPLP – Community of Portuguese Speaking Countries, has done in this regard. "The CPLP had a wonderful idea of ​​uniting us through language, but the CPLP has done vague, limited and barely visible work. In fact, very few people have done a worthy job of creating links between new Portuguese-speaking cultures. In this sense, this book fills a gap and brings new data about these new cultures, with this technological and innovative dynamic", this in relation to the QR codes for all chapters of the book. Each code gives access to a video that summarizes the author's work in each chapter. In global terms, “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures” aims to be comprehensive in areas such as technology, art, culture and social communication. There is, however, “a common denominator, creating, curiously, a certain harmony, even with different focuses, and ends up covering, directly and indirectly, the spectrum of social communication”, he concludes.

item.title: STD | Portuguese market is a priority
item.description: The director of the Tourism Services (DST), Maria Helena de Senna Fernandes, said that Portugal will be one of Macau's priorities when it comes to attracting more foreign visitors. In a message broadcast by public broadcaster TDM – Teledifusao de Macau, regarding the Lunar Year of the Fire Horse, Senna Fernandes pointed out among the targets for this year “European markets, such as Portugal and Spain”. The director also mentioned Southeast Asia, Northeast Asia – a region that includes Japan, Mongolia and the Far East of Russia – and “the emerging tourist markets in the Middle East and Central Asia”. Senna Fernandes predicted that Macau will receive 41 million visitors in 2026, after reaching close to 40.1 million visitors last year, a new historic high. The majority (90.6 percent) of tourists came from Mainland China or Hong Kong. Tourism | Flat orders to encourage consumption Deputy Chan Lai Kei wants the Government to draw lessons from tourism statistics and visitor consumption patterns to implement measures that increase tourists' stay in Macau and commerce in residential neighborhoods off the tourist trail. In a written question, the deputy linked to the Fujian community indicated that during this Lunar New Year, the Government invested a lot of resources into organizing large events, which failed to benefit small and medium-sized companies in areas less popular with tourists. Chan Lai Kei argues that the Government should improve the transport system during national holiday periods, in order to facilitate visits to residential neighborhoods, far from the most popular tourism centers. The deputy also asked the Sam Hou Fai Executive for practical measures to improve the experiences of international tourists and eliminate current obstacles, such as the lack of international electronic payments and language barriers. Performance Venue | IC will launch new measures The president of the Cultural Affairs Bureau (IC), Deland Leong, revealed that the IC will launch an online platform for companies to consult rental requests for the Macau Open-Air Performance Venue. The changes are part of the Government's objectives to “expand and reinforce the functions” of the concert venue and were revealed on the morning program Forum Macau on the Chinese channel Rádio Macau. This objective had previously been revealed by the secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, during the presentation of the Lines of Government Action, in the Legislative Assembly. At that time, the secretary pointed out that in the future the space could receive 3×3 basketball courts or other facilities for family sporting activities. Deland Leong also acknowledged that the Government will review some of the regulations and guidelines for the use of the space.

item.title: Borders | Secretary wants security against external forces
item.description: The Secretary for Security promised that the region will strengthen border security in 2026, “to avoid interference from external forces”. Chan Tsz King highlighted the importance of collaboration with secret agencies in Mainland China and Hong Kong The Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, committed to strengthening security at Macau's border posts throughout this year, “to avoid interference from external forces”, but without pointing out any threats. “We will further enhance security surveillance at sea and land ports to prevent interference from external forces,” Chan told public broadcaster TDM – Teledifusao de Macau. In a message regarding the Lunar Year of the Fire Horse, which began last week, the leader did not identify the threats coming from abroad, but promised to “fully safeguard national security”. “We will continue to strengthen our intelligence collection and analysis capabilities, especially through ongoing intelligence exchanges with mainland China and Hong Kong,” Chan Tsz King also said. In November, the secretary promised to create, in 2026, a risk warning system against national security and warned against “acts of interference and destruction” by “external forces”. Dangerous discord On July 31, Macau police announced the arrest of former deputy Au Kam San, a Portuguese citizen, in the first case under the national security law. On February 5, the director of the Judicial Police assured journalists that there was sufficient evidence to justify Au Kam San's arrest. “There is a lot of evidence and we are entering the trial process, so we cannot disclose the details,” said Sit Chong Meng. Three days earlier, human rights organization Human Rights Watch said Au Kam San's case illustrates the “erosion of autonomy and fundamental freedoms” in Macau. In November, the head of the European Union (EU) Delegation in Hong Kong and Macau wrote on social media that he had met with Macau's Secretary for Economy and Finance, Anton Tai Kin Ip. “I also expressed concern about political issues,” added Briton Harvey Rouse. But the EU representation declined to reveal to Lusa whether the case against Au Kam San was mentioned at the meeting. In September, during a visit to Macau, Prime Minister Luís Montenegro admitted that he did not discuss the detention of the Portuguese citizen with the territory's leader, Sam Hou Fai. “There are some issues that also deserve some modesty in their treatment and this is one of them”, defended the prime minister.

item.title: Taxis | Women want the Government to control applications
item.description: The Women's Association argues that the use of online platforms to hail taxis should be subject to a permanent control mechanism by the Government. The opinion is contained in a document released on Friday by the association, which has two representatives in the Legislative Assembly, at a time when Uber, a non-Chinese application, began operating in the Macao SAR. The association states that the objective would be to allow the Government to know in real time the needs for taxis in the territory, through the use of artificial intelligence technologies. Focusing on peak hours and holidays, the approach will enable coordination with platform operators to dynamically allocate transport capacity, improving cross-district coverage and reducing taxi downtime. The “systemic approach will increase the operational efficiency of taxis”, it was argued.

item.title: Justice | Deputy says closed door trials do not violate Basic Law
item.description: Deputy and deputy director of the Faculty of Law of the University of Macau Iau Teng Pio defended that holding trials linked to national security behind closed doors does not violate the Basic Law of the Macao SAR. In an article cited by public broadcaster TDM – Teledifusao de Macau, Iau argued that “the principle of exclusion of publicity” does not amount to “an absolute secret” of the trial. In the article, published on Friday, the deputy argued that the proposal “is in accordance with the spirit” of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), applicable in Macau through the Basic Law. Iau argued that a closed-door trial remains “a fair process” because lawyers maintain “different procedural rights”, which prevent “secret negotiations”. The jurist highlighted that countries such as France and Germany – with civil law, similar to that used in Portugal, which served as the basis for Macau's legal system – also provide for the exclusion of advertising in cases involving “state secrets”. In the article, Iau does not make any comment on the restrictions on the appointment of a lawyer in national security cases, something that analysts interviewed by Lusa consider unconstitutional.

item.title: New Year | Sam makes “wishes of peace and prosperity to the great country”
item.description: The Chief Executive entered the Year of the Fire Horse with desires for national prosperity and pointed to “new horizons” for Macau, under the “firm” leadership of President Xi Jinping In the traditional speech to enter the Lunar New Year, the Chief Executive left wishes for “peace and prosperity to the great Fatherland”. The message was conveyed in a recorded video, released on the eve of the Lunar New Year. "The bell for the Year of the Horse will ring. At this moment, Spring is felt in all its splendor in Macau and this pearl shines incessantly in the palm of the motherland's hand", said Sam Hou Fai. “I wish peace and prosperity to the great country; to the MSAR, I wish stability and prosperous development; to all the residents of Macau, I wish you happiness and good health,” he added. Regarding the entry into the new year, the ruler stated that the “horse symbolizes loyalty, courage, exploratory spirit and freedom” and that these qualities “must be promoted” to face “the future”. “Ahead of the Year of the Horse, we must, with a spirit of leadership, courage and perseverance, promote the development of Macau in all aspects in the best possible way; we must, with persistence and dedication, continue to adequately carry out work to improve the lives of the population for their well-being”, he highlighted. Get stronger In the message, the Chief Executive also highlighted the need for the Macao SAR and the country to continue to strengthen themselves to achieve new successes. “As the Chinese quote says: ‘The movement of heaven is vigorous; therefore, a noble person must strive tirelessly to strengthen himself’”, he stressed. "The success story of the 'One Country, Two Systems' principle in the Macao SAR has been written generation after generation by the people of Macau. I am convinced that, under the firm leadership of Mr. President Xi Jinping and the Central Government, counting on the great Motherland as unwavering support, as long as we have the courage to reform and innovate, better leveraging the institutional advantages of the 'One Country, Two Systems' principle, we will certainly be able to achieve success, opening up new horizons of development and creating new splendid successes”, pointed out the leader of the Macao SAR Government.

item.title: Economic Housing | Requested dates for exchange arrangements
item.description: Deputy Nick Lei wants to know when the Government will present the economic housing exchange scheme. The matter appears in a written interpellation presented by the legislator. The affordable housing exchange aims to help households move into apartments that keep up with the growth in membership. The deputy linked to the Fujian community recalled that the Secretary for Transport and Public Works, Raymond Tam, stated that he will develop this regime in accordance with the results that foresee the optimization of housing policy in Macau over the next five years. The study was completed last year. The deputy also wants to know when the Government will implement the permanent application mechanism for economic housing, instead of the competition application model, as this type of housing is sufficient to satisfy current demand. Nick Lei also argues that it is necessary for the Government to review the intermediate housing policy, and asks whether a new study and a new public consultation can be carried out.

item.title: Nipah | Request for more virus prevention
item.description: Representative Leong Hong Sai defended, according to the newspaper Ou Mun, that there should be better prevention against the Nipah virus during the Chinese New Year, which is approaching, even though the virus does not have a significant impact on the territory. The deputy hopes that residents ensure personal protection and hygiene, taking into account that a period is approaching when many people travel, with Leong Hong Sai adding that it is important to reinforce, on the part of the Government, border supervision, without forgetting temperature measurement for suspected cases. The deputy also considers that the Executive must ensure the coordination of hygiene work in community work, reinforcing the frequency of cleaning and disinfection actions in streets with a greater concentration of people. Leong Hong Sai also hopes that authorities will soon complete the Nipah virus emergency response plan.

item.title: Total unconsciousness
item.description: 19 dead following the bad weather recorded in Portugal for two weeks. 19? It's true, unfortunately there were two more deaths due to total unconsciousness last week. On the second day of Storm Kristin, the waters of the Mondego River began to rise and the worst was expected. The river's flow began to flood several lands and invade several roads. Mr. Venâncio and Ms. Fátima, residents near Soure, in the municipality of Montemor-o-Velho, decided to take their Citroen and go to Coimbra for a medical appointment, when the municipal authorities were already starting to warn people not to leave their homes. It was a Tuesday and in the afternoon Civil Protection announced that several regional roads were closed to traffic because of the floods that were progressing due to the increase in the flow of the Mondego River. Mr. Venâncio, aged 68, and his wife, aged 65, finished their hospital appointment in Coimbra and decided to return home. They still had dinner in the student city at a family member's house, but they didn't want to stay the night in the house where they were staying or spend 70 or 80 euros on a hotel room. They even decided to return home, despite having finished watching on television during dinner that the roads around Montemor-o-Velho were dangerous. There they went. At one point, Mr. Venâncio called a friend saying that he wasn't orienting himself very well on which route to take and that the road he was on was unfamiliar to him. The friend understood that Mr. Venâncio would be lost, because he shouldn't even be behind the wheel due to having recently had some mental disorders that could indicate some type of dementia. Mr. Venâncio's total unconsciousness caused him to enter a road that was already covered in water and the car slid into a rice field that was already completely flooded. Hours passed and the couple's daughter began to get worried, her parents' cell phones were not responding and she decided to alert the police authorities. From then on, for almost a week, the television channels only reported that a couple was missing. The searches were incessant. A huge effort by divers and maritime patrols, firefighters and GNR soldiers. Days later and after the water level began to drop, some hikers saw the roof of a car immersed in the rice field and alerted the authorities. The confirmation deeply saddened the population of Varride, where Mr. Venâncio and Ms. Fátima lived. Their bodies were inside the Citroen and the number of flood victims was 19. Now, it is time for reconstruction in several affected areas, especially in Leiria and Marinha Grande. In the debate in the Assembly of the Republic with the presence of the Government, the Prime Minister announced his full support for the victims of the calamity, despite there still being many people who did not receive government support and who were left with nothing in the latest fires. An important note: the exemplary work of the president of Coimbra City Council. Ana Abrunhosa received the greatest praise from all quarters, except from the Chega party, because Abrunhosa was not a populist and a demagogue. The district of Leiria was the area most affected by the storms and where there was the greatest destruction, where between five and eight million trees fell, but we can announce first-hand that the city council of Leiria has already invited a personality who left behind vast and commendable work in the afforestation of Macau while he lived in the former Portuguese colony. Engineer António Paula Saraiva was invited to study the reconstruction of the main garden in front of the City Hall and where almost all the trees fell due to strong gusts of wind. António Saraiva has already visited the site and was immediately ready to study the arboreal reconstruction of the Leiriense garden. A round of applause for this exceptional technician, who, despite being retired, was immediately ready to cooperate for the well-being of Leirienses who enjoy visiting his main garden. Reconstruction of the destroyed areas will be hard and expensive work. It could exceed 10 billion euros, but as Luís Montenegro said in Parliament, it will have to be a reconstruction carried out by all Portuguese. The country continues, life does not stop, but we hope that promises do not fail, as has been recorded in other cases. Portugal was in the news for the worst reasons contemplated by natural phenomena, but Portugal will be in the news again when it can announce to the world that the Portuguese people affected by a calamity have returned to their normal lives.

item.title: You need to know how to govern
item.description: On the day the Minister of Internal Administration took office, we spoke to a commander of the National Republican Guard (GNR) who told us “Oh, my dear, this minister Maria Lúcia Amaral is going to be a disaster... you are a very good jurist, but you don't have the slightest ability to deal with men with wiry beards, nor do you have the slightest idea of ​​what the security forces are and what needs to change in such a disturbed and obscure panorama”. The commander was right. The minister was a black page of the current Government and ended up resigning in times of calamity. He had to resign forcibly. He was already a “jester” within the PSP, GNR and Civil Protection. You left the country astonished when it was only three days after Storm Kristin hit Leiria and Marinha Grande that you came out to say… nothing! Several politicians and television commentators had long called for the Prime Minister to replace the Minister of Internal Affairs. Luís Montenegro turned a deaf ear and the result was the same as the catastrophe that has hit the national territory. Montenegro looked around at his friends and did not immediately find a new minister for such an important portfolio. Montenegro does not have a vision of reality. By the way, Portugal has a personality who should immediately be invited, if he were willing, to occupy the position of Minister of Internal Administration. Only Admiral Gouveia e Melo knows how to coordinate the Armed Forces with the GNR, PSP, Fire Department and Civil Protection. And it was seen in the Covid-19 pandemic. We did not vote for presidential candidate Gouveia e Melo, but we recognize his stance as an organizer, coordinator and with seriousness in taking the position of Minister of Internal Administration in difficult times for the country, which finds itself from North to South in a situation of tragedy. Last week, the unimaginable happened. No one, much less an infrastructure official, ever thought that the country's main highway, the A1 that connects Lisbon to Porto, could collapse due to the rupture of a dike on the Mondego River. In the Coimbra area, motorists will be unable to use the highway for months. We always come back to the same thing: we need to know how to govern. And the Government, at the beginning of the storms that have ravaged the country, was not up to the tragic events. It did not even include the storage of a substantial amount of generators in the planning for a new blackout or other type of catastrophe. It would be the least. More than 20,000 Portuguese people are still without electricity, two weeks after the first storm that knocked down power poles and flooded gas stations. The truth is that thousands of Portuguese people have been displaced from their homes and evacuated from villages surrounded by water. In the Coimbra area, the marines never stop transporting people, food and other goods in their amphibious vehicles for a day. There are people who are left with nothing. A life to build a house and from one day to the next they found themselves completely without what they had gathered for years. The lands in various parts of the country are saturated with water and in the near future, according to experts, these lands will collapse and the houses that are in their path will be destroyed. Even in Porto Brandão, next to Trafaria, and in Costa de Caparica, the cliff collapses left hundreds of people homeless. And for years, the Almada City Council did not foresee that the tragedy could happen? We have many competent mayors in Portugal, but we also have incompetent and corrupt ones who only care about building roundabouts and other megalomaniac works for the Spanish to see. The reconstruction of this calamity that hit Portugal will take years and one of the most important works, the installation of underground electrical lines, has already received the “solidarity” verdict from the European Union: it does not grant support for this. And this is how the Portuguese are witnessing a flooded country, with agriculture destroyed, with houses and factories that have disappeared and with an endless line of trucks that transport much of what feeds the population, due to a highway viaduct that collapsed, and who knows how it was built... we just hope that in the future they will know how to govern with the aim of providing the Portuguese with a better and more peaceful life.

item.title: Camões, the maricón
item.description: He was a Christian, baptized António and was born on the island of Java, hence the gentile name Jau, who gives his name to a street in Lisbon, at the intersection of that of the Lusíadas. Luís Vaz would have met this new friend of his following a shipwreck in Cambodia – perhaps when he passed through the land of “loving Malays, brave Jaus” (X.44.4,7) coming from Macau, where he had never been. Ou enquanto esperava por uma nau que o levasse a Cochim e depois a Goa, cerca de 1565. Ou conheceu-o mesmo em Goa, a Sodoma do Oriente. A partir desse momento, António não mais o ia largar até à morte de Luís. Expirou nos braços do seu escravo. This is the myth, of course. The only historical sources we have are the first Camonian biographers, Pedro Mariz, Severim de Faria and Manuel de Faria e Sousa, who rarely refer to him. Those who are more attentive (and also those who are in the know) realize that what existed between Luís and António was a loving relationship. Not a loving relationship as we would understand it today, but a connection with hierarchies, perhaps fixed places. Camões was much older, a washed-up man in his late forties; Jau was a newly racialized young Christian in Lisbon. It was certainly forbidden for him to walk wherever he wanted. On the street, I should go shopping and little else, or ask for him on the streets of Lisbon, as some say. At home, he acted as a nurse, perhaps a servant, perhaps a lover. In Camões literature, or literature that has recovered this theme, Jau plays several roles: faithful friend, canine, Camões's alter ego, confidant, soulmate or even subliminally a boyfriend, which comes to the surface in some less naive, more knowledgeable texts. After all, the smartest people understand what was encrypted so as not to be understood. In the biographies and literature produced on this topic (which even enchanted Portuguese, German and French romanticism: we have paintings, plays, poems – even operas, on the subject!), he usually accompanies the Poet in the ambiguity of friendship until the end of his life. But a slave friend. Tradition began, however, to identify him as a slave only after a saying by Manuel de Faria e Sousa. A commentator who they call fanciful, but who perhaps knew what he was doing. After all, isn't slavery a metaphor for love, which Camões himself uses? Whoever says Bárbara, says jau. It is an obvious literary metaphor about the chains of affection, a code shared between his closest friends and some later ones who understood the allusions, probably a humanist homosocial circle and their descendants. It has already been suggested that Jau had been bought and rescued in Goa by the Poet, who had gone into debt because of the servant; that this same Jau, who would be an interpreter, was shipwrecked with his master at the mouth of the Mecong and went with him to Mozambique and from there to Lisbon. Poignant legends, but unlikely, says Storck. In fact, António died before the poet, and the latter only managed to survive him for a few months. This is the little information we have. As the German biographer recalls, all slaves had to pay freight to come to the Kingdom and then, in Portugal, entry rights, owed to the King. Who would pay them, if not poor Luís? This shows that he was not a slave at all. Camões did not have the resources to make a blind man sing, let alone own a slave. Storck again: a Jau slave who spoke three languages ​​fluently (his Javanese, plus Chinese and Portuguese) would certainly not be cheap. There were even Jau slaves in Lisbon. There was no need for Luís to bring one from so far away. João de Barros bought one, apparently Chinese. But the historian had a broad purse, and the Poet not so much. Now, this memory also comes with regard to the recent film El cautivo (2025), by Amenábar, which tells how Miguel de Cervantes was captured by privateers and locked up for five years in an Algiers prison. There was some controversy when the film suggested the possible homosexuality of the national author. This issue is not new, and there are disputes in Spanish criticism about his sexuality. Were you accused of sodomy or not? At least here there is a discussion, while in Portugal the suggestions about the same in Camões are light, distant, flying. Fernando Arrabal, author of Un esclavo llamado Cervantes, explained that his biography, published in 1995, is based on a document, dated 1569, according to which Miguel de Cervantes was accused of homosexuality when he was 21 years old and condemned by the King of Spain to the amputation of his right hand and exile. Was that why Cervantes had no use of his arm? And there are Cervantists who in fact speak not only of their homosexuality but also recognize their Jewish origins. The latter also came forward for our Luís, through Fiama's pity. They are metaphors for each other, if we look closely. Things seen as other, prohibited, that must be kept secret, and for which only small, closed groups hold the hermeneutic key. But after all, these are things that are within so many. They are also metaphors for each other: being Jewish is a metaphor for homosexual, and vice versa. In addition to being, or having been, concrete possibilities of life, they are also signs for some life that is behind the sign, the verb or the image, and that we do not achieve. Amenábar takes sides, of course, and does it well, in a beautiful film that transforms Miguel into Scheherazade who, together with her lover, the Bey of Algiers, postpones his death with stories. I think it's an excellent film, as entertainment, even if it's too focused on Cervantes as a storyteller, when Cervantes is far from being just that. Our Spanish brothers, on the other hand, even found the film mild and not very sexualized. In Portugal it would perhaps be a scandal if they did something like that for Camões. Many would think that they wanted to muddy the water. A good film would be one that gave a face to his abandonment, in which only with Jau did he find refreshment. Mário Cláudio, Eugénio de Andrade and Alfredo Margarido were among the few who dared to go there. The point I want to reach is the following: it would not be so much to present a gay Camões, but rather to show how his life and work open up to other landscapes, also sexual, as Frederico Lourenço says in the entry on Love in the Camões Dictionary, by Aguiar e Silva. It's for the next centenary.

item.title: The Dispute over Greenland (II)
item.description: “Nations do not compete for land; they compete for the power that land unlocks.” Halford J. Mackinder The position of the European Union (EU) in the face of the United States' growing attention to Greenland, intensified during Donald Trump's presidency, generated concern and strategic reflection. Although Greenland has not been part of the EU since 1985, the island remains part of the Kingdom of Denmark, a Member State of the Union, which gives the issue an unavoidable political and institutional dimension. The European position thus results from the need to protect the territorial integrity of one of its members, to safeguard strategic interests in the Arctic and to preserve the stability of transatlantic relations. The EU views Greenland as part of the broader European political space, not because of its formal membership, but because of its constitutional connection to Denmark. Any external attempt to acquire or exercise control over territory is interpreted as a direct interference with the sovereignty of a Member State. The American proposal to purchase the island was received in Brussels as a disruptive diplomatic gesture, which went beyond the traditional limits of cooperation between allies. The defense of Danish sovereignty constitutes the first pillar of the European position. The EU has reiterated that the territorial integrity of its Member States is non-negotiable and that any change to the status of a European territory requires full and voluntary consent from national and local authorities. The idea of ​​a territorial transaction, reminiscent of 19th century practices, contradicts contemporary principles of international law and European governance. The EU recognizes the Arctic as a region of growing importance, both for its environmental relevance and its geopolitical value. The accelerated melting of ice, the opening of new maritime routes and access to strategic mineral resources transformed the region into a space for competition between great powers. The EU, which defines itself as a “global actor”, seeks to ensure that the Arctic remains a zone of peaceful cooperation, governed by multilateral norms and shared management mechanisms. American interest in Greenland is interpreted in Brussels as part of a broader strategy of military and economic assertion in the Arctic. Although the United States is a fundamental ally within NATO, the EU maintains reservations about unilateral initiatives that could alter the regional balance. The excessive militarization of Greenland, particularly through the possible installation of nuclear weapons, would be seen as a factor of instability, with a direct impact on European security. Greenland has vast reserves of critical minerals, including rare earths, essential for the energy transition and the European technology industry. The EU has sought to reduce dependence on external suppliers, especially China, and sees cooperation with Greenland as an opportunity to strengthen its strategic autonomy. The American interest in controlling these resources raises concerns in Brussels, which fears an excessive concentration of power over vital supply chains. The EU argues that mining exploration in Greenland must be carried out in a sustainable, transparent manner and in partnership with European actors, guaranteeing benefits for the local population and avoiding predatory exploration practices. The EU deeply values ​​the transatlantic relationship, but considers that strong alliances require mutual respect and predictability. The American proposal to acquire Greenland was interpreted as a gesture that disregarded European political sensitivity and put trust between partners at risk. Brussels sought, however, to avoid a diplomatic escalation. The European response combined firmness in defending Danish sovereignty with discursive moderation, in order to preserve strategic cooperation with Washington in areas such as defense, trade and international security. The EU stressed that dialogue on the Arctic should take place in multilateral forums and within the framework of NATO, and not through unilateral initiatives. Trump's statements at the 2026 Davos Forum further intensified these tensions. Before global leaders, Trump stated that the United States “will not use force” to acquire Greenland, although he stressed that the country would be “frankly unstoppable” if it decided to do so. He added that “no other nation can defend Greenland” and that Washington intended to begin “immediate negotiations” to take control of the territory. In one of the most controversial passages, he declared: "We want a piece of ice to protect the world, and they won't give it. You can say yes and we will be very grateful, or you can say no and we will remember." Trump also reinforced the historical narrative according to which the United States “saved Greenland” during World War II and insinuated that returning the territory to Denmark would have been a mistake. He repeated criticism of NATO, accusing European allies of contributing little to common security, and threatened to impose tariffs of 10% on several European countries, increasing to 25% if the sale of Greenland did not go ahead. European reactions were immediate and firm. Danish Foreign Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen considered it “positive” that Trump had taken the military option off the table, but stressed that “the president’s ambition remains intact” and that American pressure continued to be unacceptable. In Brussels, the statements were interpreted as a rhetorical escalation that undermined trust between allies and sought to transform Greenland into an instrument of economic and strategic blackmail. European diplomats called the speech “bellicose” and “out of line with the spirit of cooperation” expected at the Davos Forum, noting that the threat of tariffs on EU Member States constituted a form of coercion incompatible with stable transatlantic relations. Denmark, although responsible for Greenland's foreign and defense policy, faces specific challenges in managing the territory. The island's growing autonomy, combined with interest from external powers, places Copenhagen in a delicate position. The EU has sought to support Denmark, strengthening its negotiating capacity and offering instruments for economic and scientific cooperation with Greenland. Brussels understands that the region's stability depends on a balanced relationship between Denmark's interests, the aspirations of the Greenlandic population and the need to avoid external interference that could compromise European security. Therefore, the EU's position regarding the American interest in Greenland is based on three fundamental principles; the uncompromising defense of the sovereignty of a Member State; the preservation of stability and cooperation in the Arctic; and the protection of European strategic interests in critical resources and regional security. Trump's statements in Davos reinforced the European perception that the issue goes beyond a mere territorial dispute, revealing an assertive American strategy that combines economic pressure, historical narrative and geopolitical ambition. Although it recognizes the importance of the transatlantic partnership, the EU rejects unilateral approaches that could weaken the European political balance or transform the Arctic into a stage for confrontation between great powers. Greenland, located between continents and between logics of power, has become a test of the EU's ability to assert its strategic autonomy and protect its members in an increasingly competitive international context.

item.title: More Chinese New Year shows in the coming days
item.description: The Directorate of Tourism Services (DST) continues to organize, in the coming days, shows to celebrate the arrival of the Year of the Horse with fireworks. One of the initiatives is the holding of three editions of “2026 – Drone and Fireworks Shows”, where drones are introduced for the first time in this type of presentation, in a combination of “technology with art, increasing the sensation and appreciation of fireworks shows”, in order to “enrich festive experiences”. One of these presentations takes place today, the seventh day of Chinese New Year, and then on March 3, the fifteenth day of the first month of Chinese New Year. These shows take place in the bay next to the Macau Tower. Also noteworthy is the holding of the “Second parade of floats with cultural performances” on Saturday, the 28th, the 12th day of the Lunar New Year. Between 8pm and 9:30pm, and starting at Rua Norte do Patane, the parade also includes a cultural show in the Iao Hon Municipal Market Garden. There will be 17 floats in this parade, eight of them representing Government departments and the remaining nine from local tourist entities. The public will be able to watch this parade from its beginning, on Rua Norte do Patane, and along the pedestrian walkways on the parade route to the finishing point, in the Jardim do Mercado Municipal de Iao Hon. Galloping on ZAPE At ZAPE, the “Gala a gallop no ZAPE” initiative is taking place until the 1st of March, “in conjunction with Chinese New Year and Valentine's Day”, more specifically in the surrounding area between Rua de Cantão and Rua de Beijing. According to a note from DST, the aim is, “through installations characteristic of the festive season, to increase the festive atmosphere of the neighborhoods and the tourist attraction, attracting people to the community neighborhoods”. This “Gala galloping at ZAPE” has “the participation of ZAPE traders and several integrated tourism and leisure companies”, and includes the launch of promotional packages to attract more tourists.

item.title: Concert | “Classics on Strings” in March at CCM
item.description: March will be the time to host the “Clássicos em Cordas” concert, led by the Macau Orchestra, and which brings two violinists to the territory: Julian Rachlin and Sarah McElravy. Here's the opportunity to hear interpretations of compositions by Beethoven and Felix Mendelssohn Bartholdy The Macau Orchestra (OM) will be the protagonist of another classical music concert scheduled for March, namely on the 14th, and which will be performed in the large auditorium of the Macau Cultural Center (CCM). The concert will be directed by Julian Rachlin, considered a “world-renowned violinist”, as described in a note from the Cultural Institute (IC), which supports the show. Violinist Sarah McElravy also joins the stage. “String Classics” is the name of this show, which presents “a true feast of fascinating works for strings”, such as Beethoven’s “Coriolanus Overture”, Mozart’s “Symphony Concertante in E-flat Major” and “Symphony No. 3 in A Minor ‘Scottish'” by Feliz Mendelssohn Bartholdy, German composer and pianist. This last composition dates from 1829 and 1841, having been premiered in the city of Leipzig on March 3, 1842. It is one of the last major works composed by this master of Romanticism, with its composition beginning on a trip to Scotland. In the case of Beethoven's “Coriolanus Overture”, it lasts eight minutes and had its premiere in Vienna, in March 1807, and is known for having inaugurated two concert formats in the 19th century, namely the concert overture and the symphonic poem. Distinguished names In a note from the IC, the career of Julian Rachlin, born in Vienna, is described as an “internationally acclaimed Austrian violinist and violist”. Rachlin also collaborated “with numerous orchestras and several internationally renowned conductors for more than three decades”, and, in recent years, he was Principal Guest Conductor of the Royal Northern Sinfonia, in the United Kingdom. He also directed several international orchestras, such as the Oslo Philharmonic Orchestra and the Munich Philharmonic. Sarah McElravy, a Canadian violin and viola player, has performed on stage in Europe, America and Asia. She is “recognized for her exceptional technique, having collaborated with renowned orchestras and participated in several music festivals”. McElravy is seen as someone with “profound performance experience”, also dedicating herself “to promoting musical education, having founded a chamber music association in Mexico to bring world-class concerts to local communities”. The “Clássicos em Cordas” concert will last approximately one and a half hours, including an intermission. Tickets are now on sale, with prices ranging between 150 and 300 patacas.

item.title: Timorese Maria do Céu Lopes protects heritage of ‘tais’, traditional fabrics
item.description: East Timorese Maria do Céu Lopes discovered the cultural importance of ‘tais’, cloths woven by women, in Timor-Leste during the war and cooperation with the resistance and today protects almost 400 examples, while waiting for a museum. Although he used 'tais' in some ceremonies during his childhood, it was only later, with his cooperation with the resistance and his curiosity, that he discovered its profound cultural value. Then comes the challenge of a childhood friend, António Coelho, specialized in fabrics, to preserve the ‘tais’. It was with his colleague that he began studies to collect information about those aspects associated with all the important moments in the life of a Timorese, but along the way he created, in 1999, Timor Aid, a non-governmental organization to protect the Timorese cultural heritage. “Timor Aid managed to do it, we have a collection of almost 400 pieces, some old, some copies of the old ones that we saw in the book that António gave us”, Maria do Céu Lopes told Lusa. In addition to collecting oral information, Timor Aid also documented in audiovisual the entire traditional process of producing a 'tais', including how cotton is dyed from natural plants, established a network of weavers to protect the tradition of confection and also a store in Dili. UNESCO recognition Their effort, out of “faith and conviction”, was recognized when the ‘tais’ was inscribed in 2021 on the List of Intangible Cultural Heritage in Need of Urgent Safeguarding of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO). “The recognition, the merit, is not ours, it belongs to the weavers and our ancestors”, he stated. Maria do Céu Lopes explained that that textile has a “very important role in Timorese domestic life”, in addition to identifying the linguistic group of those who use it and the community to which they belong. “The ‘tais’ is used from life to death, when a child is born the first thing to do is wrap it in a ‘tais’ and then so on: ‘barlaques’ [a type of dowry], funerals, the ritual ceremonies of ‘uma lulik’ [sacred houses]”, he said. “A woman, in ancient times, her dignity, her social position, was due to the ‘tais’ that she wove, because nowadays the ‘tais’ has value in money, but in the past it was in buffaloes, ‘morten’, traditional necklaces, ‘belak’ [used in necklaces] and gold”, he highlighted. Asked by Lusa about whether ‘tais’ could be lost, Maria do Céu Lopes considered that it could not. “But, the quality of modern ‘such’, few are good”, he lamented, highlighting that it is necessary to certify the product due to prices and for people to have the guarantee of what they are buying. Maria do Céu Lopes also lamented the lack of a museum to showcase Timorese heritage, which is seen in museums abroad, giving the Louvre as an example. “You want a museum, I want a museum because I have the material to put it in, it’s not for me it’s for Timor-Leste, we don’t have a decent cultural center, not even in Dili”, he lamented. "We don't do anything here. I can't build a museum, I don't have money," he added. While waiting for the museum, the Timor Aid collection will continue to be protected and waiting for dignity to be seen by the tourists, which Timor-Leste intends to attract.

item.title: K-Pop | Mark Tuan performs at Studio City in March
item.description: Mark Tuan, singer of the K-Pop group GOT7, performs in Macau on March 28th at the concert “Silhouette: The Shape of You FANCON ENCORE”, presenting songs from the new album with the same name. Tickets have been on sale since Friday On March 28th, the Studio City Event Center hosts what promises to be a great show for K-Pop lovers. This is the performance of Mark Tuan, member of the famous group GOT7, who is presenting the concert “MARK TUAN – Silhouette: The Shape of You FANCON ENCORE”, which aims to “celebrate Mark's musical evolution, offering an intimate vision of a personal journey of growth” of the musician in the world of shows and records, describes a statement from Studio City. Tickets have been on sale since Friday the 13th, with prices varying between MOP899 and MOP2,199, and all ticket holders can have access to an additional offer, namely an autographed poster and “the opportunity to participate in a ‘Hi-Bye’ session, offering an interactive experience that goes beyond expectations”, it is revealed. The show, in a format closer to fans, will show how Mark Tuan has, as a singer and songwriter, “continued to expand musical boundaries”, developing “a distinct style in recent years that combines alternative rock with pop influences”. Mark Tuan has been on the road with this tour for a long time, now ending in Macau. Such a show will “further enrich the city’s live entertainment panorama, providing the public with high-quality cultural experiences”, describes Studio City. Songs in the scream This is also an opportunity for Mark Tuan to present his second mini-album, “Silhouette”, which features the emotionally charged lead single, “Sunsets and Cigarettes”; and a “tender serenade” called “Pretty Little Picture”. This is followed by the “visionary” song called “Autopilot”. This record is like “a private diary”, capturing “[Mark Tuan’s] transition and transformation through music and images, offering a glimpse of the path forward in his musical evolution”. GOT7 was born in South Korea in 2014, under the umbrella of JYP Entertainment, and has seven singers, one of them Mark Tuan, who has excelled in a solo career.

item.title: Suicide | Cáritas Support Line received around 30 calls per day
item.description: Between the 16th and 19th of this month, the last three days of the last lunar year, the Caritas suicide prevention helpline entitled Caritas LifeHope received around 30 calls daily. The number was indicated by the person responsible for the telephone line, Ng Lai Ieng, cited by the newspaper Ou Mun. The person in charge explained that the number of daily calls was similar to that on other business days. Ng Lai Ieng revealed that seven of these calls were requests for help related to suicide, but fortunately they were nothing more than thoughts, without any type of planning or associated action. Ng pointed out that in these cases the calls are classified as low-risk cases. The other requests for help were motivated by marital conflicts or problems adapting to situations of divorce, stress, and other cases of mental and emotional instability. Anyone who is emotionally distressed or considers themselves to be in a desperate situation should call the Caritas Hope for Life Hotline on 28525222 in order to obtain emotional counseling services.

item.title: Portugal | BNU and Misericórdia join the solidarity campaign
item.description: Six Portuguese-based entities in Macau and Hong Kong announced a fundraising campaign to help victims of the storms in Portugal. After Cáritas Macau, the solidarity wave encompasses BNU, Misericórdia, Casa de Portugal, Council of Portuguese Communities, Lusophone Scout Group of Macau and Club Lusitano After Cáritas Macau announced about two weeks ago that it was raising funds to help victims of the storms that affected Portugal and Spain in recent weeks, the solidarity campaign in Macau and Hong Kong was extended to six Portuguese-based entities. Monetary donations can go to an account at Banco Nacional Ultramarino (BNU), which has joined the initiative, according to a joint statement. The funds will then be redirected “to one or more Portuguese social solidarity institutions operating on the ground, ensuring transparency and traceability of the entire process”, they added in the same note. Recalling the “best tradition of fraternity and solidarity that unites Portuguese-speaking peoples”, the statement makes “a public appeal for the mobilization of the Portuguese-speaking community in Macau and the Greater Bay Area”. In addition to having the institutional support of the consulate, the campaign was launched by the Casa de Portugal association in Macau, the China Circle of the Council of Portuguese Communities and the Lusophone Scout Group of Macau. Long challenge In Hong Kong, the initiative has the participation of Club Lusitano, the largest institution of the Portuguese-descendant community of the former British colony, with around 400 members, founded in 1866. It is worth remembering that on February 10, the Catholic organization Cáritas Macau launched a three-month fundraising campaign for those affected by the storms in the Iberian Peninsula. In a note published on social media, the Catholic organization lamented the “devastating storms” that caused “catastrophic floods” and landslides in Portugal and Spain, destroying infrastructure and homes. "Thousands of people are homeless and urgently need water, food and medical care. Local teams work tirelessly, but the recovery will be long and challenging", warned Cáritas Macau. On Wednesday, the União das Misericórdias Portuguesas said it had received a donation worth 300 thousand euros from Misericórdia de Macau to support its counterparts who suffered significant damage caused by the Kristin depression. Nineteen people died in Portugal following the Kristin, Leonardo and Marta depressions, which also caused many hundreds of injuries and displacement. The total or partial destruction of homes, businesses and equipment, the fall of trees and structures, the closure of roads, schools and transport services, and the cut of energy, water and communications, floods and floods are the main material consequences of the storm. The Centre, Lisbon and Vale do Tejo and Alentejo regions were the most affected. The calamity situation that covered the 68 most affected municipalities ended on February 15th.

item.title: Health | Registration open for training in clinical medicine
item.description: Registration for the “training course in basic clinical medicine skills” is open until March 4th”, the Health Services said on Friday. The course, organized jointly with Hospital das Ilhas and Hospital Kiang Wu, aims to “raise the level of healthcare services”, “promote the synergistic development of public and private healthcare systems”, and “improve the technical capabilities and competitiveness of healthcare professionals in Macau”. This training course will be taught by doctors from the Health Services, and from the Islands and Kiang Wu hospitals, with a program focused on the systematic introduction to basic clinical medicine skills for generalists and resident doctors. 50 vacancies will be available for professionals interested in becoming general practitioners or resident doctors in public or private hospitals in the region. The training sessions are scheduled for the weekends between the 7th and 22nd of March in the multifunction room of the Macau Medical Academy, in the Dynasty Plaza Building, in Alameda Dr. Carlos d’Assumpção, Macau. The courses will be taught in Chinese.

item.title: Birth rate | Expected rate increase of 4.5 percent
item.description: After visiting the first babies of the Year of the Horse, Tai Wa Hou indicated that the expected increase is due to the fact that the Government has launched “high quality services” to promote birth rates The leader of the public hospital predicted that there should be more than three thousand births in 2026, an increase of at least 4.5 percent, in the region with the lowest birth rate in the world. According to the Chinese language channel of public broadcaster TDM Macau, the deputy director of Centro Hospitalar Conde de São Januário said he was confident that young couples in the territory would have more children. After visiting the first babies born in the Lunar Year of the Fire Horse, which has now begun, Tai Wa Hou defended that the Government launched “high-quality services” to promote birth rates. In July, the local parliament approved a budget review to reinforce social support, including the creation of a subsidy, worth a total of MOP54,000, for children up to three years old. The Government also launched a public consultation on the increase, in the private sector, of maternity leave, from 70 to 90 days, and annual leave, from six to 12 days to “obtain a better balance between work and family life”. The mother of the first baby of the year, born at 00:11 in Conde de São Januário, surnamed Fung, told TDM that she plans to have more children and hopes that the newborn will grow up with “many siblings”. The estimate made by Tai Wa Hou still represents a drop compared to the forecast made almost a year ago, also on the first day of the Lunar New Year. Black numbers On January 29, 2025, the deputy director of Macau Health Services, Kuok Cheong U, predicted that the year would end with fewer than 3,500 births. On January 1st, Tai Wa Hou revealed that Macau registered 2,871 newborns in 2025, the lowest number in almost 50 years, since 1978, when the city, then under Portuguese administration, registered 2,407 newborns. However, while in 1978 Macau had less than 249 thousand inhabitants, at the end of September 2024 the region already had a population of almost 687 thousand. The number of births thus fell for the sixth consecutive year and is increasingly far from the historic maximum of 7,913, set in 1988. Macau recorded just 0.58 births per woman in 2024, far from the value needed to replace generations (2.1), the lowest fertility rate ever in the region and the lowest in the world, according to official data.

item.title: Study warns of cognitive impact of short videos on children
item.description: Two researchers from the University of Macau concluded that short-form videos used on social media and viewed on “scrolling” on cell phones negatively impact children's cognitive development, potentially causing social anxiety and insecurity. “Compulsive consumption of short videos has a negative impact on cognitive development, which can cause lack of concentration, social anxiety and self-doubt”, he explained to Lusa Wang Wei, academic in the field of Educational Psychology at the University of Macau (UM), author of the study “Addiction to short videos, school involvement and social inclusion among Chinese rural students”. “This short video design can be particularly dangerous for children”, warned the researcher. “Our research indicates a direct correlation: the more students consume short videos, the less they engage with school,” Wang continued. Wang argues that, although children's fundamental psychological needs must be met offline, the architecture of short video platforms, with personalized algorithms and social interaction features, directly and subtly meets these same needs. This parallel satisfaction, Wang's research suggests, “potentially leads to overuse and addiction.” “The stimulating and fast-paced nature of short videos makes them highly entertaining for students,” the researcher added. Attention required Anise Wu Man Sze, professor of Psychology at UM's Faculty of Social Sciences and author of the study “The relationship of affective and cognitive components in the problematic use of short videos”, adds to Wang's conclusions the issues related to the overstimulation of children, which further harm healthy cognitive development. The short videos capture everyone's attention precisely because “they are right there at hand and they are free”, highlights Wu, speaking to Lusa. People can access vast amounts of short videos “anytime, anywhere”. Now, these addictive behaviors often originate from a “functional purpose”, he explained. “We have to raise awareness, especially if use starts to affect daily life, leading to the sacrifice of family time, neglect of sleep, or people surfing at inappropriate times, such as during classes or driving, putting themselves or others at risk,” he told Lusa. As for interventions with children, according to Wang Wei, “it is very important” to satisfy their emotional needs, while cultivating digital literacy and self-regulation skills, “instead of limiting ourselves to taking away their cell phone”. By December 2024, the number of people with access to this type of videos in China reached close to 1.1 billion individuals, with 98.4 percent being active users of this format, according to the Annual Report on the Development of Audiovisual Services on the Internet, published by the Chinese authorities.

item.title: Restoration | After Macau, Manteigaria moves to Hong Kong
item.description: Manteigaria is linked to the Portugália Restauração Group and aims to open at least three stores in the HKSAR within a year. However, the future could lead to expansion into more markets, such as Mainland China, South Korea or Japan The Portugália Restauração Group will open the first store in Hong Kong of Manteigaria – Fábrica de Pastéis de Nata in April, the group's managing partner in Macau told Lusa. "It's a real and ongoing project. It's been a little delayed, but we already have the space identified [and] it will go into construction right after Chinese New Year", in the Central area of ​​Hong Kong Island, said Diogo Vieira. The Lunar New Year holiday period, the scene of the largest annual migration in the world, takes place this year between February 15th and 23rd in mainland China. “We are very excited and very happy to be able to enter that market, which has a different dynamic”, said the managing partner of Grupo Portugália Restauração in Macau. Vieira highlighted that Manteigaria has bigger plans for Hong Kong, “a city with at least seven million inhabitants, with a very large area, with many tourists, with very populated areas, where it is possible to expand quickly”. “It is the brand's objective, within a year, after opening the first one, to be able to open at least three stores in different locations in Hong Kong”, revealed the executive. Show Portugal “We want to show locals and tourists who visit Hong Kong that it is possible to have a product that comes from Portugal (…) and show the manufacturing, the Portuguese tradition”, said Vieira. After Hong Kong, the executive revealed, Manteigaria's “expansion project” will look at “other surrounding markets”, including mainland China, South Korea, Singapore and Thailand. The brand opened its first store in downtown Macau in January 2025, followed by a second store on the island of Taipa in November, and, said Vieira, currently employs “between 25 and 30 people”, selling an average of 2,500 pastries per day. The Manteigaria operation in Macau “is profitable and growing, therefore, the investment is expected to be recovered in a very short time”, added the group’s managing partner. Macau had local custard tarts on the market, inspired by the Portuguese pastry, recreated by a British man living in the city, Andrew Stow (1955-2006). Although this is “an advantage”, Vieira says that “the necessary adjustments were made (…) to market needs, desires and local culture”, with a reduction by half of the sugar used in the pastel de nata recipe. In October, the Macau Government inscribed 12 events, including local custard tarts and Portuguese folk dance, on the territory's Intangible Cultural Heritage List. A decision that will also benefit the Portuguese pastry, defended Vieira. “We with the original Portuguese version, the other local producers with the Macau version, but we all compete a little in the same environment and in a very similar product and we all end up benefiting”, said the executive.

item.title: Operator Melco's profits quadruple in 2025
item.description: Macau casino operator Melco Resorts and Entertainment announced profits of US$185 million in 2025, four times more than the previous year. In a statement sent to the stock exchange in New York, the president of Melco, Lawrence Ho Yau Lung, says that “2025 was a year of growth and recovery, driven by disciplined cost management and the expansion of margins”. The company's revenues increased 11.2 percent, to $5.16 billion, despite closing the Grand Dragon Casino, a 'satellite casino', and three of the six gaming machine rooms it owned in 2025. The 'satellite casinos', under the responsibility of the concessionaires, are managed by other companies, being a legacy of the past that already existed before the liberalization of gambling in the territory, in 2002. When the legislation regulating casinos was changed, in 2022, the end of 2025 was established as the deadline for ending the activity of these gambling spaces. Ten of the 11 'satellite casinos' closed their doors. The only survivor was Royal Arc, which was acquired by operator SJM, founded by the late gaming mogul Stanley Ho Hung Sun, who took over direct management of the space. High pace Melco's revenues rose faster than the sector in general. Macau casino revenues grew 9.1 percent in 2025, reaching 247.4 billion patacas. Lawrence Ho, son of Stanley Ho, highlighted that the company's operating profit in Macau rose 25 percent last year, to US$1.23 billion, “driven by more robust gaming revenues and margins”. Melco operates in Macau, as well as in Cyprus and the Philippines, having opened a casino in Sri Lanka in August. Melco expects to spend around 10 billion patacas in the non-casino segment within a decade, including on “the only water park in Macau with indoor facilities open all year round”. The company highlighted the relaunch, in May, at the City of Dreams hotel-casino, of the largest permanent show in the territory, The House of Dancing Water, which had been suspended since June 2020, due to the covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke long and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. It says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this error. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything?
