How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. I don't always know all the winners – I didn't know about the existence of Louise Glück, who I think is a great poet, or Olga Tokarczuk, for example – but this only brings me the comfort of knowing that the world is not a soap opera where everyone knows everyone else and the joy of recognizing that the yardstick of the world is not measured with my short measure and that, on the contrary, it gives me a new opportunity to face the unknown and learn from it. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English. I would also prefer that, in French, Pascal Quignard, Linda Lê or even Sollers were awarded, or, among the new ones, Mathias Énard, but that does not detract from the dignity of Annie Ernaux's work (and it would have been enough to have written “Les Années”). There are books of hers that I like less, like the vulgar “Uma Paixão Simples”, but that happens with almost all authors, they have pivotal books and others that are like breaks in their itinerary. I recommend reading a beautiful book of interviews with her, “L’écriture comme un couteau”. 11/10/22 Yesterday an article appeared in the morning newspaper “Notícias”, in Maputo, reporting that the Pen Club Narrative Prize had been awarded to my wife, Teresa Noronha, for her soap opera “Tornado”, which had already won the Maria Velho da Costa Prize. The summary they made of the book does not even deserve comments, as it is pathetic, but what is important to highlight is the note of disqualification regarding its “Mozambicanness” when they call it Luso-Mozambican. It's not that it's inaccurate, but, for those who know the context, it's a touch naughty. Because finally, following the same logic, Adelino Timóteo should be called Tsonga-Mozambican, Álvaro Taruma Ronga-Mozambican, and Macua-Mozambican for writers from the north, etc., etc. Which doesn't appear to happen. At one point, in the novel, she writes: «Our color was never the dominant one. In colonial times we were not white, we were dressed in monhés, mugs of washed asses, the pejorative term to speak of a son of Goan and Portuguese. In the post-colonial period, I was not black and if, in Lisbon, they took me for Brazilian or Cape Verdean, in France they were lost in thought about where I was from and were surprised when they discovered that I was African. There I had to explain the wanderings of my DNA before settling in Mozambique. It took me a long time to accept that it was like that because yes, and that it was no curse that that was the case; on the contrary, I could even discover intense patterns of fantasy and freedom in this harlequin cloak that is our genealogy…” In modern-day Mozambique, it means being white… and that immediately takes precedence over what you do or what you are. It's sad, but as Naipaul warned, in these parts race is everything and people live as deeply immersed in it as, in other places, in religion. 12/10/22 Bruno Latour, an anthropologist who studied the sciences and their procedures and legitimations, law, technique and religions and who entertained himself by turning his back on the dogmas of the “moderns”, has died. For him, the place, the role of the specialist, was defined more by the perplexity he embodied than by the supposed truth that would sustain him. He proposed, as an alternative to the goodness of multiculturalism and its equivocal cliché “all different, all equal”, a return to “diplomacy”, given that this, precisely, does not start from the assumption that “we are unified because we share the same nature” but simply highlights that we “still do not share a common world”; It is necessary that we deal head-on with the “abyss of disagreement” that separates us, instead of trying to deceive it. And about politics he said, boldly: «If transparency is demanded from politicians, we kill them; if anyone demands fidelity to what the other was or what he says, kill him; If a mimetic relationship is required between what the crowd wants and what its representative says, representation is killed. These must therefore, by definition, betray, deceive, modify, distort the word. Without this ability to bend the word and betray, political language would not exist. I put forward the perfectly plausible hypothesis that political vocabulary will become as inaccessible as the religious language of the last twenty, three or fifty years.» (in “Un Monde Pluriel mais Commun”). I believe we will be needed to decipher this frantically complex world that has fallen to us.

item.title: Fuxi
item.description: O my friends, companions of these disastrous journeys through countries as old as the stars and the Moon, and as strange as the deepest interior of our wretched souls, what surprises still await us, what secret magics will we still have to overcome, what horrors will arise before our pupils dilated with astonishment and terror? Increasingly closer to our precarious existences, howls the monster of war, which threatens to merge humanity once and for all with the earth, incessantly traversed by the squalid specter of hunger and the invisible evil of ten thousand pestilences. Oh damned human, who believes you are superior to Nature itself, but then you reveal yourself, time and time again, incapable of simply ordering your existence and do not understand that you are possessed by fickle anger and are a slave to your own ambition! You are not satisfied with white jade or resplendent gold, there is no treasure that quenches your inextinguishable thirst for command over other men, animals and things; for eternal anguish dwells in you; in you the expelled serpents crawl; for you grows, powerful and impressive, the most fertile ivy of Evil! This is perhaps why on the Mount they call the White Deer, where one of the eight immortals on a sacred mount soared through the heavens towards Penglai, lives the fuxi, a bird whose shape resembles that of a rooster, although topped by a human head. What strange copulations, what monstrous embraces, what terrible procedures must have occurred to make the existence of this sinister animal possible? We don't know, but all it takes is for our exhausted mind to dare to come up with an answer, and then we feel our skin covered in horrendous goosebumps and our heart races in parade, like a wild horse whipped by the night whip of fear, unresponsive to reins and containment. Let men refrain from visiting Monte do Veado, because although there are riches capable of calming the wildest ambitions, if they have the unfortunate luck of catching a glimpse of a fuxi, it is certain that a war will soon break out and the cultivated fields will perish, because of it the tame animals will be beheaded, because of it the best young men of two generations will be sacrificed and the pride of the countries will be destroyed. The fuxi makes a sound reminiscent of its name. If you hear it, dark night or clear day, be on your way, because the path you are on is the surest path to misfortune!

item.title: Procrastinators Club
item.description: While rereading Easter, because of an article I'm preparing, I come across this excerpt, taken from “The Universal Man”: «Each man, morally, is one and absolute; but he has to live with attenuating his personality. (…) Coexistence is only possible between people reduced to a negative or hollow presence, which constantly gives way. Hence, the emptiness of society, an immense ghost made up of countless dead people. A superior man is antisocial or criminal. His destiny is prison and the desert”. I hesitate to think whether Pascoaes reflects here on the political-social conditions that muzzle, and, worse, in a sad country like Portugal in the middle of the Estado Novo (and the book is from 1931) where any possibilities of spontaneity and frankness in human relationships were restricted, or if it merely lends to the behavior of (oppressed) men a metaphysical framework, an “essence”, declared in the presumption of each being, in isolation, “one and absolute”. Sometimes, in addition to an excess of Spirituality (or Saudade), Pascoaes lacks the world. He is a great poet, but he is a poet who takes Ampoules-of-Great-Ideas and who therefore writes often trapped by a programmatic furor, ceasing to have pores; It is not uncommon for a glass to be erected between him and reality, the same glass that made him write in O Bailado, from 1921: «Everything is a ghost. There are only clouds, clouds of voices, clouds of souls, of afflictions and tragedies! Clouds and more clouds, appearances and more appearances! And a divine lightning that pierces them, the instantaneous Apparition that appears and throws us to the ground, dazzled!» Sometimes I felt like reminding him, as António Sérgio did, in the article “Regeneration and Tradition, Moral and Economy”, which he dedicated to Pascoaes: «Pascoais, Pascoais my dear friend: you are a pure, excellent and noble poet, but also a victim of this social environment, like us all: of this horrible isolation that you praise and I curse». «As a child, he stole two blackbirds», says Jacinto do Prado Coelho, he stole them from a nest, and he felt remorse for that all his life. The Person, few more mischiefs are known to him. Only in Álvaro de Campos does a hint of wickedness and obscenity emerge: «Ah, and the ordinary and dirty people, who always look the same,/ Who use swear words as usual words,/ Whose sons steal from grocery store doors/ And whose daughters at the age of eight – and I think this is beautiful and I love it! –/ Decent-looking men masturbate in stairwells.” (Triumphal ode). Both poets, driven by a certain idea of ​​sanctity, had the same inability to break the siege of their skin with the overflow of someone else's dam, the same curse of sublimating the concrete ferocity of eros with the gentleness of the verses. Obviously, they are both “bigger than life”, but sometimes it makes me unnerved to watch, from my position as a hatter at the Procrastinators Club, the tantrums between them, just to see who occupies, in the internal organization, the position of President and Treasurer. Although Pessoa guessed more things, for example, what he wrote in the lesser-known Ode Martial and which is reflected in the situation we live in today, in a different way, with his heart in his hands: «MARTIAL ODE (…) Helahoho! helahoho! The poor widow's sewing machine who was bayoneted... She sewed indefinitely in the afternoon… The table where the old people played, Everything mixed, everything mixed with bodies, with blood, All one river, one wave, one dragging horror. Helahoho! helahoho! I unearthed the child's tin train pressed into the middle of the [road, And I cried like all the mothers in the world about the horror of life. My pantheistic feet tripped over the sewing machine [widow who was killed with a bayonet And that poor instrument of peace stuck a spear in my heart. Yes, I was the one to blame for everything, I was the soldier for them all Who killed, raped, burned and broke, It was me and my shame and my remorse like a shadow [misshapen They travel around the world like Ashavero, But behind my steps there are footsteps the size of infinity And a physical fear of being accountable to God makes me close my eyes. [eyes suddenly. (…) I ordered, captain, to shoot the trembling peasants, I let the daughters of all fathers tied to trees be raped, Now I saw that it was inside my heart that all this happened, And everything scalds and suffocates and I can't move without it [everything be the same. God have mercy on me, I didn't have it from anyone! LÀ-BAS, JE NE SAIS OÙ…” What is clear today, at this disastrous moment in which Cristiano & Companhia failed in their mission in Braga, and in which the self-sabotage of Russia's gas pipelines reminds us that Putin will indeed be willing to do anything to maintain dominance over the areas endorsed, is that, bomb for bomb, the “bomb” of the Fifth Empire was preferable. However, even in this, my dears, we were irresolute, a little more on the side of piela than determined, and we procrastinated.

item.title: Fees | Asia responds to new US announcements
item.description: Several countries and regions in Asia reacted Saturday to the US Supreme Court's decision that annulled the tariffs imposed by the President, as well as the new 10 percent global tax that Donald Trump instituted after the court decision. Tokyo rules out that the invalidation of the rates will affect previously agreed investments, according to the economic newspaper Nikkei, while Taiwan and Hong Kong foresee a “limited” effect of the new global tariff. China has not yet commented. In response to the resolution, which invalidates the so-called “reciprocal tariffs” and other generalized taxes applied by Trump, with a minimum rate of 10 percent, the President signed a global tariff of 10 percent on all countries. The law that supports this new executive order only allows tariffs to be increased by up to 15 percent and for periods of 150 days, so it is not clear how it will be articulated in the long term, writes the EFE news agency. South Korea said the trade deal with Washington, which provides for commitments such as a $350 billion South Korean investment and 15 percent tariffs from Washington, remains intact. According to Yonhap news agency, South Korean authorities called an emergency meeting to assess the impact of invalidating the tariffs. The governments of Taiwan and Hong Kong consider that the 10 percent global tariff announced by Trump will have a “limited impact” on their economies. Indonesia, which on Thursday signed a trade agreement with the US, indicated that it will hold “new talks” with Washington in light of the “dynamics that are occurring”. Malaysia assured that it “will continue to diversify its trade relations and strengthen regional and multilateral economic cooperation”, despite the decision that invalidates a large part of Trump's tariffs.

item.title: Thailand | Virus kills 72 tigers in wildlife park
item.description: Authorities in northern Thailand said 72 tigers have died in recent weeks at a wildlife park due to a viral and bacterial infection. The tests detected the presence of the highly contagious canine distemper virus, as well as bacteria that affect the respiratory system, the Chiang Mai Provincial Livestock Department said in a statement on Friday. "When tigers get sick, it is more difficult to detect the disease than in animals like cats or dogs. By the time we realized they were sick, it was too late," said the director of Thailand's Department of Livestock, Somchuan Ratanamungklanon, to local media. The cats belonged to the privately owned Tiger Kingdom wildlife park. Tourists can “hug, touch and take up-close photographs with the tigers” there, according to the park's website. “These tigers died as they lived: in suffering, captivity and fear,” animal rights organization PETA Asia told France-Presse news agency. “If tourists avoided these places, they would quickly become unviable and tragedies like this would be much less likely to occur,” the organization added.

item.title: Hong Kong | Hong Kong government demands Japan protect residents after Sapporo attack
item.description: The Hong Kong government said it has demanded Tokyo protect residents of the Chinese region who visit Japan, after a resident was targeted in an attack in Sapporo. The Hong Kong executive “expressed concern” to the Japanese consul general in the territory, Jun Miura, and urged Japanese authorities to “guarantee the personal safety” of Hong Kong travelers in Japan. In a statement released on Thursday night, the territory's authorities said they are collaborating with Beijing's diplomatic representation in Hong Kong and the Chinese consulate in Sapporo, in northern Japan. The objective, explained the Hong Kong Government, is to “understand the situation, follow up on the case and provide practical assistance in accordance with the wishes” of the resident targeted by the attack. The Chinese consulate in Sapporo said the man was hit in the head with a beer bottle at a restaurant in the early hours of Wednesday, and that Japanese police had already detained a suspect. China's diplomatic representation once again recommended that tourists not travel to Japan, because “the trend of attacks in Japan against Chinese citizens has been increasing”. However, Hong Kong tour operators told the South China Morning Post that the attack was likely an isolated incident that would not affect residents' interest in visiting Japan.

item.title: Lunar New Year | Consumer spending to grow
item.description: Chinese consumers welcomed the Spring Festival holiday with an explosion of spending, crowding restaurants and shopping malls and traveling across the country, which provided a boost at the beginning of the year for the consumer sector, according to Xinhua. In the first four days of the holiday, average daily sales at major retail and catering companies increased by 8.6 percent compared to the same period last year, according to data from the Ministry of Commerce. The spending spree mixed tradition with new habits, with online platforms reporting strong demand for smart devices. Spending on services contributed to the boost. Domestic tourism consumption on major platforms rose 4.5 percent year on year in the first three days of the holiday, including a 26 percent jump in car rental bookings. The government has introduced a series of support measures ahead of the nine-day holiday, encouraging local authorities and businesses to combine promotional events with political incentives, including shopping vouchers and better payment services for visitors.

item.title: White House | Donald says visit to China will “be wild”
item.description: The White House announced that Donald Trump will make an official trip to China, from March 31st to April 2nd. Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping have already met in person five times. "I'm going to China in April. It's going to be wild," Trump said on Thursday. This visit takes place after the US Supreme Court of Justice partially annulled the customs duties that Trump had imposed. These rates have been one of the main sources of tension between the US and China. The trade dispute calmed down with an emergency agreement, in May 2025, in Geneva, which was consolidated for a year, since October 2025, when China lifted restrictions on its exports of so-called rare earths and the USA reduced part of the tariffs. Donald and XI must also address bilateral technology relations and security in the Asia-Pacific region, in addition to the specific issue of Taiwan. At the end of 2026, in the opposite direction, Xi Jinping is expected to move to the White House.

item.title: Visit | German Chancellor in Beijing this week
item.description: Friedrich Merz arrives in the Chinese capital on Wednesday, his first trip to China since taking office as chancellor last year The German Chancellor, Friedrich Merz, will carry out a state visit to the People's Republic of China this week and until February 26th, the Government announced Friday. Merz leaves Berlin on Tuesday and arrives in Beijing on Wednesday, being received by the Chinese Prime Minister, Li Qiang, and is also scheduled to meet the President, Xi Jinping, said a spokesperson for the German Government. The visit will take place at a time when Beijing authorities present themselves as more of a trustworthy partner for Europeans, especially in contrast to the United States. This is the first visit to the People's Republic of China since Friedrich Merz took office as chancellor in May 2025, and takes place just a few days after the end of the Lunar New Year celebrations. The German Government spokesperson added that discussions will focus on bilateral relations, as well as issues of economic and security policy, highlighting Berlin's desire to maintain “fair relations” with Beijing in commercial terms. On Thursday, the German Chancellor will visit the Forbidden City, in Beijing, before a meeting with a delegation from the German automobile group Mercedes-Benz, where new vehicles are expected to be presented. Full schedule The official agenda includes a visit to Hangzhou, a city on the east coast of China, as well as two business trips: one to the company Unity, a robotics group, and to the German energy company Siemens Energy. The two countries have strong commercial ties, which are currently strained due to accusations of unfair competition and protectionism directed at Beijing. Even so, Berlin and Beijing have demonstrated a willingness to overcome differences, particularly in the context of the world order imposed by the current United States Administration. In mid-February, on the sidelines of the Munich Security Conference, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi told Merz that he viewed Berlin as a “driving force” in cooperation between the EU and China. Economically, the relationship between Berlin and Beijing has changed drastically in the last decade, with China going from the best customer of German export industries to the main competitor. The German economy is experiencing difficulties and Chinese competition is causing concern for some German companies, particularly in the automotive sector.

item.title: China asks US to make 2026 a year of “peaceful coexistence”
item.description: China and the US must make 2026 a year of convergence for “mutual respect, peaceful coexistence and mutually beneficial cooperation”, said the head of Chinese diplomacy, Wang Yi, to his US counterpart, Marco Rubio. Wang and Rubio met on Friday on the sidelines of the Munich Security Conference, according to a statement published Saturday on the official website of the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs. “Dialogue is better than confrontation, cooperation is better than conflict, and mutual gain is better than the zero-sum (mentality) in relations between China and the US,” said the Chinese foreign minister. Wang assured that, as long as Washington and Beijing “respect the principles of equality, respect and mutual benefit”, they will be able to “find ways” to resolve tensions and manage differences “appropriately”. “Both sides should work together to continuously expand the list of areas of cooperation and reduce the list of problems, so that China-US relations are on a stable, healthy and sustainable path of development, sending a positive message to the world,” added the head of Chinese diplomacy. Positive signs According to the statement, Wang and Rubio concluded that the meeting was “positive and constructive” and agreed to “facilitate high-level interactions” and “strengthen dialogue and cooperation in various areas.” The United States Department of State has not yet released any information about the meeting, nor has Rubio done so on social media. The meeting precedes the expected trip by North American President Donald Trump to China next April — the exact dates have not yet been confirmed — during which, according to the local press, an extension of the one-year trade truce that the Republican President sealed in October with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, could be signed, after months of confrontation over tariffs. Furthermore, Trump recently stated that Xi will also visit the United States “later this year”, although this visit has not been officially confirmed either. The statement makes no reference to the issues addressed by the two presidents in a phone call last week, such as Taiwan, described by Xi as the “first red line” in relations with the United States, a subject he suggested Trump address “with the utmost caution” after the latest arms sale to the self-governed island. This Friday's meeting was the second in person between Wang and Rubio — sanctioned by China in 2020, when he was a senator from Florida, due to protests in Hong Kong and sanctions for Xinjiang —, after the meeting last July, on the sidelines of a summit of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

item.title: Kim Jong-un prepares to name daughter heir, writes Seoul
item.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un is preparing to name his daughter Ju-ae as successor, a deputy said after a meeting with the secret services, as he prepares for the grand power ceremony in Pyongyang this month. The Kim dynasty has ruled the country with an 'iron fist' since its founding in 1948, with Kim Jong-un succeeding his father and grandfather. The current leader, who maintains secrecy about his descendants, increasingly appears with his teenage daughter, Kim Ju-ae, at important official events, leading us to believe that she is the favorite for the succession. “South Korea's National Intelligence Service (NIS) estimates that Kim Ju-ae is about to be named successor,” Rep. Lee Seong-kweun said yesterday after a meeting with the NIS. The information is based, in particular, on a visit in January to the Kumsusan Sun Palace – where the founder Kim Il-sung and his son and second supreme leader, Kim Jong-il, rest -, during which Ju-ae paid homage to his ancestors alongside his father. Love Stories At the ruling party congress in Pyongyang at the end of the month, the Government is expected to reveal national guidelines, from foreign policy to the economy, including defense and advances in nuclear weapons. The meeting also often serves as a platform to announce changes in the leadership of the Workers' Party of Korea. Analysts believe that Ju-ae could be appointed first secretary of the central committee, that is, number two in the PTC. The existence of Kim Jong-un's daughter was revealed in 2022, when she watched with her father the launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile. Official North Korean media refer to Ju-ae as the country's “beloved daughter”, or even “great guide”, qualifications normally reserved for North Korea's supreme leaders and their heirs.

item.title: Public competitions | New plan to integrate AI into hiring
item.description: Chinese authorities yesterday released a strategy to accelerate the application of artificial intelligence (AI) in public tenders, with the aim of increasing efficiency, strengthening supervision and ensuring a “fair and efficient” distribution of public resources. The document, issued by the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC, China's main economic planning body) together with other state institutions, defines that, by the end of 2026, some provinces must fully implement features such as irregularity detection, AI-assisted evaluation and identification of collusion in tenders. The plan foresees the extension of these practices to the entire country by 2028. Among the planned applications, the following stand out: analysis of sectoral trends, balance between supply and demand and regulatory background checks to help define technical and commercial requirements during the preparatory phase of competitions. During the preparation of specifications, technology must allow the early detection of illegal clauses or clauses that restrict competition. Have sense On the competitors' side, AI will be able to support the preparation of proposals, the analysis of risks of contractual non-compliance and the verification of the documentation presented. The plan emphasizes, however, that conclusions generated by artificial intelligence systems do not replace the independent judgment of the parties involved nor do they exempt their respective legal responsibilities. Strict compliance with registration, review and security requirements for the algorithms used is also expected, to mitigate risks such as lack of transparency, errors or biases. The announcement comes amid the rapid expansion of the Chinese AI ecosystem, driven by the launch of advanced language models by companies such as Bytedance, DeepSeek, Alibaba and Baidu and growing political support for technological self-sufficiency. China seeks to consolidate its own capabilities in models, data and computational infrastructure, in a scenario of growing rivalry with the United States in the field of artificial intelligence.

item.title: Marcelo Loureiro, author and teacher: “The indigenato was a continuation of slavery”
item.description: He was recently in Macau to present the book “Colonial Citizenship: law, race and rights through the Portuguese empire”. Marcelo Loureiro's work explores the way in which, in the Portuguese empire, Portuguese citizenship was shaped according to skin color. Macau was no exception, although with different contours compared to Africa, argues the professor at the University of Leicester Image: Rui Cunha Foundation How did this investigation begin and how did the themes of colonialism and citizenship emerge? Everything was born from a personal and family experience. I grew up in Rio de Janeiro, in a family marked by the Portuguese diaspora on the one hand, and colonial silence on the other. A minha avó paterna, portuguesa, guardava no fundo de um armário os documentos que me permitiram, aos treze anos, reclamar a cidadania portuguesa. My other grandmother, mestizo, cafuza, had no papers, no stories to tell; From her to me, there was only silence. This division, between those who have the right to documents and a voice and those who are forced to be erased, was the starting point for questioning the legal construction of citizenship and nationality. Quando cheguei a Portugal para estudar Direito em Coimbra, comecei a perceber que a lei que me reconhecia como português era a mesma que historicamente negou esse reconhecimento a milhões de pessoas com base na raça, na ‘civilização’ e na cor da pele. O livro é, em parte, uma tentativa de compreender essa estrutura jurídica de inclusão e exclusão, é uma denúncia da injustiça por detrás dos direitos. It is a denunciation of citizenship as a method of exclusion. In the context of the Portuguese empire, when did the first notions of citizenship emerge and what criteria were used? The first formal notions of national belonging in Portugal appear in the Philippine Ordinances of 1603, which establish who should be considered 'natural' of the kingdom. It is interesting to note that the inclusion of the notion of nationality was only included in Portuguese law during the Iberian Union, during the Philippine dynasty, when Spain controlled Portugal through the Habsburgs. It was in this context that Spanish law was transposed to Portugal to separate Portuguese from Spanish. However, the practical construction of Portuguese citizenship begins much earlier, in opposition: through slavery. Since the 15th century, with papal bulls (such as Dum Diversas of 1452 and Romanus Pontifex of 1454), Portugal obtained canonical legitimacy to enslave Africans and conquer their territories. Portuguese citizenship was thus constructed, in opposition to the figure of the ‘other’ – the Moor, the black, the pagan, the ‘savage’, and finally, the ‘indigenous’. Quais eram os critérios de diferenciação? The criteria were essentially civilizational and racial: being Christian and, progressively, being white or recognized as ‘civilized’ according to European standards. Conversion to Christianity functioned, at times, as a kind of 'spiritual whitening', but even converts rarely achieved full legal equality, which continued to be imposed for centuries. The law called indigenous to all those who existed outside the standard of civilization expected of citizens, which were the non-white populations of Angola, Mozambique, Guinea and Timor. Macau will always have occupied a “privileged position” in the context of this empire. Specifically, how? In terms of citizenship, Macau has never been subject to the Indigenous Statute, which was in force in Angola, Mozambique, Guinea and Timor. This exclusion was not accidental. The Indigenous Statute applied to populations considered 'uncivilized' according to European racial and cultural criteria, being, in practical terms, essentially black populations from continental Africa and Timor. In Macau, the Chinese population, often called ‘Macau Chins’, although not European, were treated differently. There were laws that regulated the rights and customs of the Macanese population, with a complete law coming into force in 1909 and only abolished in 1949, for example. The Portuguese presence in Macau has always been accompanied by several other factors, such as British influence through contact with Hong Kong, the progressive political presence of Beijing, Portuguese political instability and the questioning of the existence of the Portuguese empire itself internationally. This meant that Portugal was unable to impose in Macau a sovereignty as powerful as that imposed in Africa and Timor. Were there cases of discrimination against the Chinese and Macanese communities before the 20th century? Discrimination existed, although of a different nature than that imposed in Africa. We can even see in literature, in the works of Senna Fernandes, for example, how the existence of walls, sides and parts of Macau, sometimes even ideological, for different populations, from Chinese villages to Christian cities. The same division occurred in the world of rights, only in an indirect way, and not through the direct imposition of indigeneity and the status of second-class national. Segregation and difference occurred socially, with difficulty accessing certain careers, the lack of invitations to birthdays because they were not ‘white’. This discrimination did not take the systematic legal form of indigeneity, as stated. The Macanese occupied an intermediate position, often functioning as intermediaries between the Portuguese and Chinese. Their ‘Portugueseness’ was recognized in an ambiguous way: they were Portuguese, but of a different type. We can mention that skin color was decisive in not placing Macau under the Indigenous Statute. Yes, skin color was absolutely decisive. The Indigenous Statute was applied in Angola, Mozambique, Guinea and Timor, territories with populations that are mostly black or ‘non-white’ in the colonial sense. Portuguese law even created the term 'oceanic race' to identify Timorese during the imposition of indigenato so that they could bring this population racially closer to African populations. Macau, Portuguese India, Cape Verde, and, to a certain extent, São Tomé and Príncipe, were excluded from this classification. The official criteria established 'uses and customs' and 'civilization' as the parameters to identify these people, but in reality these categories only functioned as a substitute for race: they were race, but by another name. The populations of Portuguese India and Macau, although not European, have always been spared the application of openly racist laws, despite local practices and policies imposing, most often indirectly, restrictions on the full citizenship of these populations, as I have described. Taking into account the Indigenous Statute, what evolution can you trace in terms of the concept of Portuguese citizenship? The Indigenous Statute, consolidated in the early 1930s, represented the maximum legal codification of racial exclusion. Indigenato was a legal form of racial segregation that created two categories of being Portuguese, namely being a Portuguese citizen (white and assimilated) and being indigenous Portuguese (the majority black). The indigenous people were legally Portuguese, but they were not citizens; they did not live with access to rights, but to restrictions, they lived, as I call it in the book, in a status of ‘negatory nationality’. Indigenous people could not vote, could not move freely, did not have the right to lawyers, were subject to forced labor, paid special taxes based on race, and could not attend the same schools or hospitals as whites. The evolution of the concept of Portuguese citizenship in this context is paradoxical: formally, everyone was ‘Portuguese’, but materially, citizenship was reserved for those who demonstrated ‘civilization’ through skin color or by proving themselves to be sufficiently assimilated despite being black. Assimilation was the only legal path to leaving indigeneity, but it required proving mastery of the Portuguese language, abandonment of African ‘uses and customs’, stable employment, ‘good moral conduct’, and military service. Very few could. What are the most flagrant cases of denial of rights that you can point to? One of the most flagrant is the system of forced labor, which functioned as a continuation of slavery under another name. Indigenous people were forced to work on plantations, mines and public works, often far from their families, in inhumane conditions. Another case is spatial and social segregation: separate hospitals for whites and indigenous people, segregated neighborhoods, different schools. In Guinea, indigenous people were forced to wear necklaces with metal plates. In Mozambique they were forced to pay radio taxes if they had a device. In Timor they were required to pay taxes if they moved from one local authority to another, or when they divorced according to local customs. The archives also show cases of indigenous people who, despite having moved to Lisbon, still continued to be treated as indigenous people. All thanks to a 1955 law that imposed indigenato status on any indigenous person in any part of the Portuguese empire – which was previously only applied in indigenato colonies. This was the case of the so-called ‘Lisbon Requests’, a group of assimilation applications that I found in the Lisbon Ultramarine Archive, where indigenous people who, having emigrated to the metropolis, tried to obtain recognition as citizens. The Indigenous Statute would be abolished years later, but the effects seem to have remained. I absolutely agree. And I say more: indigenato was a continuation of slavery itself, a reflection that is still felt today by so many communities touched by the Portuguese empire. O Estatuto foi abolido em 1961, mas décadas de exclusão jurídica, educacional e económica não se apagam por decreto. African populations have been systematically denied access to education, property, mobility and political participation for generations. This explains, to a certain extent, the difference between the different parts of the Portuguese empire, where Brazil, Angola, Macau and India occupy completely different spectrums in relation to levels of protection and access to rights. When the Statute was abolished, a context of restriction and necessity was already consolidated where the black majority survived without formal education and without access to basic rights. The post-colonial effects are equally profound: indigenato taught generations of Africans that their culture, language and way of life were inferior, and that to formally be someone, to be recognized as fully human before the law, they had to become white, they had to resemble, as much as possible, the colonizer. Mas mesmo essa assimilação formal raramente se traduzia em protecção real: o reconhecimento legal não garantia acesso efectivo a direitos. A assimilação marca não só um período histórico, mas uma forma de ver, sentir e sobreviver à história colonial. This violence left marks that persist in Portuguese-speaking post-colonial societies and that can only be resolved when there is a process of acceptance, truth and reconstruction — something that the Portuguese State has not yet been able to do.

item.title: Exhibition | Eric Fok shows “Dreaming of the Occident” in Taiwan: “In Portugal, I see traces of my city”
item.description: The year began with a new project by Eric Fok, who despite living in Portugal did not leave Macau and the East. “Dreaming of the Occident” is on display at the Helios gallery, in Taipei, and can be seen until January 24th. To HM, the local artist reveals that he wants to artistically explore the universe of Vendas Novas bifana, through its connection to Macau pork chop How is the West represented in this exhibition? I've always been fascinated by the intersection between Eastern and Western cultures, and I've explored how Macau was a territory shaped by Western missionaries and navigators who brought new sciences and ideas to the East. Regarding a previous exhibition, and during the research process, I realized how rare it was for the Chinese to travel to Europe at the time of the Discoveries. I read with enthusiasm the reports of the few who did so. There are diaries that vividly recreate the dangerous sea voyages and what life was like in ancient European cities. This allowed me to project myself into their stories, bridging the gap between past and present, between East and East. These cultural differences are not just history to me, but have become a rich source of imagination for my new work. As an artist from Macau, how has the history of the territory, marked by exchange between East and West, shaped your way of thinking about this exhibition? It all started with mapping Macau for the “Paraíso” series [2014 exhibition], a project that was born out of my curiosity about the city's past in a context of rapid expansion of the tourism and gaming industries. Through this dialogue with local history, I began to truly understand the city. I went from focusing on the small details of urban life to having a macro perspective of the world, highlighting Macau's significant role in global history. This includes its status as a gateway to China during the Discoveries, its contribution to the beginning of globalization, or even being a space for the spread of Catholicism to the East. [We cannot forget] the profound influence of maritime culture. All of these themes constitute an extension of my exploration of the historical and unique experience of Macau. Can you describe in more detail the creative process for “Dreaming of the Occident”? In addition to maps of Macau, this exhibition also presents maps of Eurasia and several Asian colonies, where I explore themes such as navigation, trade and empire. My research also extends to experimenting with materials. In addition to using paper and wood, I incorporated unconventional supports, such as ostrich eggs. These objects function as canvases to narrate stories about endemic species and the history of migration, establishing a bridge between a biological and historical side. Does the exhibition intend to criticize the Western influence in Macau, reflect on it or simply observe it? In my exploration of these themes I am mainly interested in the cultural dimensions of history. When Europeans first arrived in Asia, they viewed the world from a Eurocentric perspective. The term “Far East” was not just a geographical designation, but a symbol of power and a specific vision of the world. But, on the other hand, the term “Far West” represents an initial global imagination, in the sense of being a space of mutual understanding, albeit incomplete. Today, as we live in an era of a lot of information, where connectivity is instantaneous, we have lost that sense of mystery, and my work seeks to recover a little of what is the fantasy of distance. Do you expect different readings of the exhibition or a deeper knowledge of what Macau is, in cultural and historical terms? In the creative process, I privilege personal expression as responses to society and the world in which we live. Although exhibiting in a commercial gallery inevitably brings a market dimension to my work, my focus is always on the integrity of the work. In recent years, my desire for the public to “correctly decode” my art has changed, in the sense that, although I feel deep satisfaction when someone connects with my inner world, I have come to accept this “emptiness” in the narrative of my work. These gaps are meant to be filled by the experiences and emotions of the viewer, or perhaps by time and history itself. In a time of rapid and ephemeral changes, I use the brush to document and preserve. My work consists of sharing the urban experience that invites the public to create an emotional connection with cities, promoting a deep reflection on identity and belonging. He has lived between Macau and Portugal. How does this influence your work and your view of Macau’s history and culture? At the moment I respond to this interview I find myself in Vendas Novas, a town in Portugal that is famous for bifana. I am currently exploring whether there is any direct connection between this local specialty and Macau pork chop bread. Centuries ago, the Portuguese sought to build a “home” in Macau, leaving behind Portuguese structures that defined the skyline of my city. Currently, being in Portugal, I see traces of my city everywhere. Being Asian, and being surrounded by different races and languages, I find a certain sense of belonging that can be both alienating and deeply familiar. The enormous geographical distance is shortened by culture and history, which are shared. This exchange of identities and the movement between places constitute deep inspirations for my work. Searching for an unknown place On the Helios gallery's internet portal, Eric Fok's new exhibition is described as a search for a Europe that, on the eastern side, was known to exist, but which was far from being known, especially from the middle of the 16th century, when the term “Taixi” appeared as a reference to the “Great West”. The Chinese expression was used by the Jesuit missionary Matteo Ricci and is one of the focuses of the Macau artist's work in “Dreaming of the Occident”. According to Helios' presentation, “Taixi” was a term attributed to “an extremely distant land in the West that was, once, a blank space on maps, yet to be explored”. In this way, Eric Fok's imagined maps explore the ideas of an absent and unknown place, also analyzing “the identity of the self, the transport of memories, power and ideology”. Using historical research, the Macau artist “rediscovers ‘Taixi’ from the perspective of the Far East, through writing and cartographic representation”. Eric Fok also investigated “the views of the world that existed in the past, formed by the interconnection between power and belief”, it is described.

item.title: Iranian Ambassador in Lisbon condemned “institutionalization of the improper use of force”
item.description: Iran's ambassador in Lisbon, Majid Tafreshi, condemned the “institutionalization of a new policy”, implemented with the instrument of “improper use of force”, alluding to the United States and Israel. In an interview with the Lusa agency, Tafreshi warned that this process will “spread” if countries, especially Western ones, “do not take serious measures” against the United States and Israel, “which have incited public unrest”. “There are no guarantees that such practices will not be repeated, especially when disturbing discussions are already being heard, such as those regarding the possession of Greenland”, highlighted Tafreshi, remembering the North American actions in Venezuela, and the insinuations against Colombia and Cuba. The interview took place before the diplomat was called by the Portuguese Government because of the violent repression of demonstrations against the Iranian Government, an announcement made yesterday by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The Iranian diplomat recalled having already asked his “academic colleagues” and diplomats to create in Portugal a new forum entitled “Dialogue between Enemies”, in the search for “universal peace and a world free from war and tension”, as well as the creation of new mechanisms – such as an East Asian Union – “could constitute a meaningful initiative”. “I believe that politics and politicians should follow more closely the will of their own people, who, in reality, do not seem to have major conflicts between themselves – as can be clearly seen in tourism, in football stadiums, in concerts and in hundreds of other human interactions”, argued the Iranian diplomat. Regarding recent developments in Iran, in which, he said, peaceful demonstrations focused on economic challenges, over time, “some elements present in these concentrations escalated to violent incidents”, including armed actions that, according to reports, “involved individuals with prior training”. “Regrettably, these events resulted in casualties among security forces, public order forces and ordinary citizens,” said Tafreshi, after the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Volker Türk, condemned and demanded an end to the “repression of protests in Iran, which have resulted in more than 600 deaths since December 28, according to a non-governmental organization. Iran's ambassador in Lisbon referred to the “millions of Iranian citizens” who participated in public demonstrations on Monday, “reflecting a change in the general picture and expressing support for their Islamic country”, which, as in the past, the news received limited attention from the Western media. Outside incentives Asked about what is strangling the Iranian economy, Tafreshi highlights the interventions of Israel, “to a lesser extent”, and the United States, “which have encouraged public unrest”, as well as Iran's economic challenges, which are significantly influenced by extensive sanctions imposed” by Washington. “These measures, which Iran considers illegal, have also been supported by European countries that defend human rights, despite there being concerns that such policies have negatively affected fundamental rights of the Iranian population, including access to healthcare”, he denounced. “Respect for the Charter of the United Nations, the bitter lessons of the First and Second World Wars and the devastating experiences and costs of events in Afghanistan, Syria, Palestine, Lebanon, Libya, Iraq, Ukraine and elsewhere should be enough to remind us of the urgent need to prioritize, more than ever, peaceful coexistence”, he added. Regarding the high number of fatalities, Tafreshi denied that Iranian security is using a disproportionate use of force, exemplifying, alongside the high number of deaths among civilians, the significant number of deaths and injuries among police officers”. People power Asked about the words of Reza Pahlavi – son of the former shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, deposed after the 1979 Islamic Revolution – in which he stated that he intends to return to Iran soon, Tafreshi considered that, with the “support of some Western and Zionist media”, he appears to be trying to play the role of a “Robin of the Woods”. "However, Robin Hood never called on ordinary people to resort to violence or violate international norms and principles, such as attacking embassies and diplomatic facilities. During his father's reign, despite Iran having the support of the United States and the West, the country lost its 14th province, Bahrain. Based on experience, the United States supports and exploits anyone capable of harming Iran's independence and security," he responded. Tafreshi denied, on the other hand, that the regime – “the term “regime is an illegitimate and biased expression” – is at risk, highlighting again “the millions” of Iranians who demonstrated on Monday in favor of Iran's sovereignty. “The Islamic Republic belongs to the people of Iran. Ayatollah [Ali] Khamenei is the leader of Iran and one of those citizens”, highlighted the diplomat, for whom China and Russia maintain “good relations” with Tehran, meaning it is not necessary to count on Beijing or Moscow to defend the country, which counts on its own people to protect its security and sovereignty.

item.title: Sofia Ferreira da Silva, author of a study on opera in the Mao years: “Silk Road was the biggest influence”
item.description: In “Singing the Revolution: The Role of Songs and Opera in the Spread of Communism in Mao Zedong's China”, Sofia Ferreira da Silva analyzes the way in which songs and opera spread political ideals, leaving marks on the country's cultural panorama. The analysis came from the doctoral thesis in Artistic Studies, defended by the author at Universidade Nova de Lisboa What was the musical environment like in the country before Mao Zedong came to power? China was, and continues to be, a territory with a huge variety of practices at regional, local and ethnic levels. We can speak of four main types: music of a more erudite nature, symbolized by court music (yayue) and guqin music, more centered on Confucian ideals and with ritual functions and self-cultivation of individual morals; folk music, with vocal and instrumental genres varying according to region and ethnicity; Taoist, Buddhist and other religious music; and traditional opera, such as Kunqu and Peking, Sichuan and Canton operas, combining singing, declamation, stylized movements and martial arts. The biggest influence on Chinese music was, perhaps, the Silk Road, as a good part of the musical instruments that are now considered “Chinese”, such as the erhu, the pipa, the suona and the sanxian, have their origins in foreign instruments brought to Chinese territory, and which were gradually adapted and incorporated into their music. On the other hand, some narrative and operatic genres evolved from the adaptation and combination of counterparts from the territories crossed by this route. If it weren't for the Silk Road, traditional Chinese music would be radically different. What other influences are there? The other big influence is Western music. This, despite having entered the country in the 16th and 17th centuries, was felt with greater intensity from the middle of the 19th century and throughout the 20th century. The growing foreign presence and influence led to the systematic introduction of Western notation, academic training along European lines and Western classical and popular music genres, which would be assimilated in varying ways by Chinese composers, such as Ma Sicong, Li Jinhui or Xian Xinghai, combining them or not with traditional music motifs. In the thesis, he talks about two major changes in the Mao years, with the creation of the so-called “model shows (yangbanxi)” and the revolutionary Peking operas. How did these formats help to reshape the music scene at the time? The model shows, which include Peking operas and revolutionary songs, played an important role in reforming the Maoist musical landscape, implying changes not only in musical styles, but also in the social function of music. Production became entirely subordinated to the political project of the Chinese Communist Party (PCC), resulting in the mandatory membership of artists and designated artistic associations, and the suppression, through criticism in the media, of musical elements or genres considered “feudal”, “bourgeois” or “superstitious”. In opposition, and following successive political movements and campaigns, other formats were promoted, more in line with the regime's ideals. How, in concrete terms? In the case of the “yangbanxi”, from the Cultural Revolution, the fact that they were called “model” implied that all new creations must strictly follow the aesthetic precepts established through them, especially the rules of the “basic task”, with the construction of revolutionary heroic figures as the ultimate aim of artistic creation. There were also the “Three Prominences”, with the attribution of greater or lesser prominence to a certain character depending on their degree of positivity or negativity, their function in the plot. These rules guided not only the narrative structure and the role of the characters, but also aspects such as the integration between music and gestures, the construction of costumes and sets, and the harmony between traditional and Western musical elements. This codification would aim, to this extent, to guarantee the ideological and aesthetic uniformity essential to the creation of a controlled, functional and politically effective musical culture within the framework of the objectives of the revolution. What are the main political messages conveyed through these two types of shows? The first big idea is the almost religious loyalty to Mao Zedong and the unconditional observance of his ideas. It is his thought that inspires and guides the actions of the heroes and heroic characters, the second most important category of characters in revolutionary operas, and leads them to the successful completion of the mission assigned to them or to heroic sacrifice in favor of the communist cause. The second is the class struggle as the driving force of history. We have, on the one hand, the oppressive, capitalist, imperialist and feudal class as the villain, and on the other the working people, exploited and oppressed by the former, suffering the greatest storms at their hands. The conflicts and difficult situations faced by the heroes or other positive characters, such as the death of family members, imprisonment or slavery, were always the direct expression of this struggle, and their resolution would only come from the revolutionary stance and the assumption of an active role in the construction of socialism. And the third idea present in the shows? This is collectivism, as a true revolutionary places the interests of the Party and the People above any individual dream or desire. No matter how prominent his role, the hero needs popular support to complete his mission: his aspirations are the aspirations of the people, and it is in solidarity between all that difficulties are overcome and the much-desired socialist harmony is achieved. Personal achievement only has value if it serves the collective cause, and individual sacrifice is glorified when it contributes to common progress. Operas promote, to this extent, a worldview where individual identity dissolves into the identity of the revolutionary collective, and where the active participation of the masses is not only desirable, but necessary. These were years of so-called cultural Maoism, as mentioned in the thesis. How is it characterized? Cultural Maoism presents points of contact regarding the subordination of art to politics, the valorization of the daily lives of the masses as the raw material for creation and the defense of its widespread popularization. However, it is distinguished by its emphasis on the proletarianization of the artist himself, who should abandon his position as a distant intellectual and become an active member of the working people, learning through practice and inserting himself in their daily struggles. What are the main influences of this movement? In addition to the Marxist-Leninist matrix, cultural Maoism would be marked by Confucian influences, giving art an ethical and formative function, as in Confucius, Mencius or Xunzi, art shaped character. However, in the Maoist context, this molding was channeled towards the construction of socialist consciousness and the eradication of traces of the bourgeois mentality. One of the central principles of this policy was the “mass line”, a kind of circular cultural dynamic in which popular ideas and expressions were collected and systematized by the Party, before being returned to the people in a clearer and more politically oriented way. Another aspect to consider is the appreciation of native and foreign cultural heritage, condensed in the maxim “use the past to serve the present, use the foreign to serve China”. In what way? To create new artistic works, Mao recommended the initial study of Western works, considered “scientific” and technically superior, before selectively incorporating elements of Chinese tradition. In both cases, the value of artistic forms lay in their social and political function, not in their preservation as heritage. In this context, the PCC leader proposed two criteria for artistic evaluation: the political, which required the promotion of national unity and the rejection of ideas contrary to the Party; and the artistic, which presupposed technical and aesthetic rigor following an abstract notion of “scientific criteria of art” at the service of the masses. This double requirement replaced, in Maoism, the Confucian distinction between moral quality and aesthetic quality. In these years, what were the biggest influences on songwriting? The composition of songs was greatly influenced by two great musical traditions: the native, with the use of regional melodies and motifs and those of the various ethnic minorities that make up the territory; and the Western, in which I include the Soviet musical tradition, most visible in marches and so-called “art songs”, which could be understood as a type of revolutionary ‘lieder’ or with highly politicized content. The influence of each of them was more or less visible depending on the political situation of the territory. How did the years of “cultural Maoism” change the country’s musical landscape? Some aspects of the production of Cultural Revolution operas, such as the introduction of the Western orchestra and the use of techniques from Western music, the incorporation of more realistic scenarios and the melodramatic nature of the stories influenced and continue to influence the production of new Beijing operas, especially those with contemporary or historical themes relating to the 20th century. XX. Over the last 30 years, operas with historical themes have also been produced with some of these elements, especially in terms of music and settings, such as “Cao Cao and Yang Xiu”. Some remnants of this period can also be seen in the interpretation of traditional operas, especially in the presentation of arias or excerpts on television programs. I see countless performances that combine, just like in the revolutionary repertoire, arrangements with a Western orchestra and realistic scenarios, with extensive use of new technologies. However, what I consider to be the greatest remnant of revolutionary operas will, perhaps, be a greater artistic audacity on the part of the creators of new operas. It is an issue that deserves further study by the academy, but, from my observations as a spectator, I notice a greater openness to the incorporation of elements from other arts, such as dance and theater, and a greater complexity in the characters, especially those considered negative, less antagonistic, with more nuances when it comes to motivations for acting in a certain way. It is obvious that the psychological suffering inflicted by these operas on an entire generation of Chinese people is undeniable and cannot, under any circumstances, be forgotten; however, model operas boosted the creative impetus of composers and librettists, in line with the evolutionary process, of fusion with other arts, of Peking Opera over the centuries.

item.title: Piménio Ferreira: “Anti-gypsy rhetoric has always worked in Portugal”
item.description: Piménio Ferreira, better known as Gitelles Ferreira, anti-racist activist, 34 years old, physical engineer, Romani national. He is a man with a provocative speech, a corrosive, gentle humor and a smile that leaves no one indifferent. Gitelles, we live in an intercultural land and gypsies – in particular – have lived in Portugal for around five centuries. What happens so that gypsy communities continue to be “on the margins” of so-called society? We need to change the model of society. This is extremely stratified, placing people in subordinate positions to privilege a violent minority. The white social structure is patriarchal and racist. What is called the ‘margin’ of society is in fact an intrinsic place within it, which belongs to it. In other words, gypsy people have been included in this model of society since they discovered Europe and its kingdoms. The problem is the model of society that is maintained and the place to which they were relegated and how they were relegated: with violence, in a status of inferiority compared to white people, without the right to human dignity, to found a family, to choose their own language and religion, expropriated of any and all cultural and material rights. A place built and maintained to this day by genocidal and ethnocidal violence and persecution. In 1463, Vasco Gitano was granted an estate. In 1521, the gitanos, or gypsies, were already used as a reference for everything that is considered bad in the model of society. The “counter-example” compared to white that would stand out in a positive way. The ‘angel’ and the ‘demon’; the ‘other’, the enemy; the one against whom any attack and persecution is legitimate. Including the prohibition of defending oneself, having weapons, any type of property, and the right to stay. And is it because they are denied this right to stay that we still have nomadic gypsy communities within the country today? Yes, without a doubt. There are many ways to force nomadism: directly, by prohibiting permanence and expelling with police or military force; indirectly, refusing public or private housing to Roma people, because they are Roma; and also through the gentrification process. I read the results of a survey by the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights, where it is said that approximately 80% of Roma respondents live below the risk of poverty threshold in their country; one in three gypsies lives in a house without running water; one in three Roma belongs to a family in which someone went to bed hungry at least once in the previous month; and 50% of Roma aged between 6 and 24 do not attend school. Why does this happen like this? It is the historic persecution that continues. There is no impoverishment that does not have an external cause. In this case, a political system of total expropriation is imposed on the basis of violence. As early as 1648, D João IV, the Restorer, prohibited ‘giving or renting houses to gypsies’. The same D João IV who achieved the kingdom of Portugal thanks to D. Jerónimo da Costa and his 250 Knights. The same D. Jerónimo da Costa who died defending Portugal's independence from Castile. Gypsy, like his wife and children. Among prohibitions on permanence, “that gypsies do not enter the kingdom and those who are in it leave” (D João III, 1526), ​​with expulsions, banishment to the galleys, expropriation of goods and properties, imposed with penalties of flogging, mutilation and death, systematically carried out to this day (even in 2011 the Municipal Council of Faro wanted to ban gypsies in the municipality). The prohibition of working for others (no one employs gypsy workers, and those who do do so in complete precariousness, for poorly paid positions and without rights and dignified conditions). They are unable to remain dependent on self-employment, they are unable to invest, due to extreme expropriation. They become dependent on precariousness. If you want to know what it's like to live in pure neoliberalism, get to know the lives of gypsies. The reality of these is paradigmatic of the aggression and lack of protection that the “lords” are willing to go to, for their own benefit. What are you talking about, is it economic and political power? The group of political, social, cultural and economic power. The owner, the colonizer. This group has been in power since it instituted the current system of domination. And that only makes sense within the hierarchically stratified sociopolitical model in which we live. Hence the need to put an end to ‘lords’ and establish a new model of society, healthy, free, without hierarchies or strata, whether of race, class or gender. The model in which we live leads the gypsy community (and beyond) to economic exclusion, removing them from access to the consumption of products or excluding them from their production process; political exclusion associated with lack of access to information; to education and consequently the social exclusion seen in the inequality of access to quality community areas such as restaurants, libraries, theater, cinema, concerts, healthcare, etc. How does a gypsy child feel when they realize they are not part of the whole? Children who never see themselves represented, not in films, not in books, not in cartoons, not even in an advertisement eating cereal, for example? Is this a disaster for self-esteem, is it a priori condemnation? That's really the question. Gypsy people are not “excluded from society”, on the contrary, they are included in it. The problem is the existence of what is cynically called 'social exclusion', an Orwellian term, and people are under duress. Which concentration and extermination camp. In fact, the Nazi concentration camps are a more visual embodiment of what is called 'social exclusion' and, as here, they were not an 'excluded' part of Nazi society, but rather its fundamental and characterizing structure. It is a place of violence, where people are kept by violence, dedicated to their extermination, and designed so that few people can leave. And yet they resist. Just like in the Nazi concentration camps. And what you listed as an example of the ‘consequence’ of this ‘exclusion’, is in fact the means by which this exclusion also happens and is maintained. Gypsy people are outside the cinemas, either as consumers or producers (but they go to the cinema). They are outside of school, education and the Academy. Either as ‘users’ or as producers (but they go to school and are at the basis of the construction of knowledge and academic and scientific debates). Even in the attack on the gypsy child's self-confidence, we speak of a mechanism for maintaining this situation. But gypsy people respond very well: with gypsy pride. Another resistance, another aggression. Gypsy people are thus included in society. In a place that belongs to this modern model of society. And they resist and counter the power of domination and insist on being in the city, in the cinema, in the theater, in the Academy, in all spaces. With a lot of struggle and always resisting, but they are there. Social exclusion, more than a “place outside of society”, is part of its social structure. Do you mean to say there is collective resistance? At work, already in a context of absolute precariousness, during the pandemic, gypsy people rolled up their sleeves and once again showed proactivity and creativity in adversity. They learned by watching and doing. And here, it is again women who jump to the front line, show their face, learn to use digital tools with their daughters or sons, and launch themselves into the network. And so they explore online sales as well as app-based work (transport or couriers). In housing, in a pandemic context in which evictions were not stopped – as the law itself should and dictates – residents did not stop organizing and fighting against unfair evictions and demanding dignity in housing; residents associations allied in their action with other housing and anti-racist organizations. It is also worth noting how they reinvented themselves and intensified to collect and distribute food items and mask/alcohol gel kits to the most expropriated people. Gypsies and non-gypsies. In the anti-racist fight, new movements emerged and their actions intensified through social media. People who had never organized or become active before began their first steps in activism, joining this path of gypsy and anti-racist organization and popular action. People forget, or don't want to appreciate, but gypsy action has helped to determine results in the political dispute. Gypsy citizens mobilized in large numbers and determined electoral results in the 2017 local councils, both in Alentejo and in the Lisbon Metropolitan Area, even causing electoral earthquakes. And even in the Presidential elections, second place was decided by an amount equivalent to the estimated number of gypsy voters. Apart from the non-gypsy votes that were mobilized by the action of gypsy voters. Gypsy people are even co-building power in opinion spaces, in local media, on social networks and in party and institutional political disputes. And most importantly, in popular action and in alliances with other social movements. We never stopped fighting by all means and we continued to resist. On the other hand, there is more and more hate speech, from the far right in particular. What do you have to say about that? To begin with, these speeches are historical and European. They are neither current nor “extreme right-wing”. These speeches have been adopted and delivered for a long time, even in 'democracy and freedom', by various representatives of the center-right, conservatives, center-left, liberals, liberal left, even representatives of the PCP. Anti-gypsy rhetoric has always worked in Portugal, as it is the most white-natured rhetoric. That is, it allows the creation and recognition of “white” as the superior of all. And thus please the white electorate who, when they feel good, compensate with their vote. Even if the policies implemented by your elected officials harm you even more. Finally, I would like you to talk a little about your personal experience and how you became an activist? I studied, fought for my studies, made alliances, graduated, and entered the “formal precarious” job market. I started my militant action and here I am today. We can transform this society into a better one. This certainty, combined with the fact that the current one has so much suffering, makes anyone want to have a transformative attitude. I wanted to be an ‘inventor’ (physical engineer) and an anti-racist activist. And through study (not necessarily schooling) and organization with other people, in turn, with other studies, training and visions, I learned how the world works and how it can be changed. But before transforming, we need to survive. This gives rise to two types of actions: transformative and survival. The fight against hate speech appears as survival, but its defeat will be a transformative victory. There is a lot that – as people who want a better world – we have to do, namely work to criminalize hate speech; condemn and ban organizations with racist speeches and practices; denounce the racist institutional structure and logic that organizes Power and manages community resources. And in this sense, there have been various types of actions, from petitions to demonstrations. And we need more. In addition to being a member of the SOS RACISMO movement, I participate in the Podcast “Viemos Para Ficar”, with Mamadou Ba and Joseph da Silva. And if everything goes well, we will soon start a new project. With friendly people, we also have the “Cigana Initiative” project, dedicated to reflecting and promoting transformative movements. Essentially focused on educating against anti-gypsyism, denouncing historical and ongoing genocide and working towards a new societal project. Also with new projects in the pipeline. And finally, there are always voluntary actions, without an organization, where I try to share what I discovered about Anti-Gypsyism and Romani history in schools and with interested people. In addition, there is still the struggle for housing, because evictions did not stop during the pandemic. Due to housing and employment precariousness, racialized individuals, especially Roma nationals, are the most vulnerable to Covid-19. It is essential to have actions in this area; Of all the struggles, this is the most structural, as it goes against one of the main enemies of a healthy society: the real estate speculation of this capitalist system, which puts profit and goods above people and their humanization.

item.title: Japanese Toshikazu Yamanishi breaks world record for walking half marathon
item.description: Japanese Toshikazu Yamanishi today set a new world record for the half marathon walking, completing the race, which took place in Kobe, with a time of 01:20.30 hours. Yamanishi's mark achieved today is the first to surpass the inaugural world record of 01:21.30 hours, approved by the World Athletics Council in December following the announcement that the half marathon and marathon would become the official road distances for walking events. Thus, since January 1st of this year, the distances of 20 kilometers and 35 kilometers in walking have been replaced by the half marathon (21.1 kilometers) and marathon (42.2 kilometers) Toshikazu Yamanishi, 30 years old, broke away from the lead group a little after 17 kilometers and ended up passing 20 kilometers with a time of 01:16.26 hours, just 16 seconds more than the world record for this distance that he himself set in 2025 on the same circuit. With another lap added, the two-time world champion accelerated again to win by a clear margin, in 01:20.34, with the time that constitutes the new record now awaiting the usual ratification process.

item.title: GP | Qualification races return to Zhuhai
item.description: Before the Lunar New Year, the General Automobile Association of Macau-China (AAMC) announced the calendar for the next season of its speed competitions, Macau Roadsport Challenge and GT4, which once again serve as the qualification process for the support races of the 73rd Macau Grand Prix. As in previous seasons, the mini-championship will be played over two double rounds. The Zhuhai International Circuit thus returns to the program, hosting these races for the first time since 2018. It will also be the absolute debut, on this route, of the models used in the Macau Roadsport Challenge, Toyota GR86 (ZN8) and Subaru BRZ (ZD8), which will compete for the first time outside the usual competitive context. The 2026 season also features a relevant novelty: the holding of a non-championship test race at the Zhuzhou International Circuit. The permanent route in Hunan province, which last year hosted the qualifying races organized by the AAMC, will be the stage for an optional preparation race. It should be remembered that, in 2025, the association promoted a non-championship competition after the qualification was defined, then at the Lake Ruyi City International Circuit, in Pingtan.
