The two scoring days will take place in the neighboring city of Zhuhai, both in May. The first is scheduled for the weekend of May 8th to 10th, while the second will take place between May 28th and 31st, 2026. The Macau Roadsport Challenge races will determine the qualifiers for the Macau Grand Prix of the same name, while the competitions reserved for GT4 vehicles will define the participants of the GT Cup – Great Bay Race. The competition will maintain an exclusive tire supplier, continuing to rely on Pirelli, which will ensure direct and centralized sales of the compounds. During the test race, the use of tires purchased in 2025 will be permitted, but in the qualifying races it will be mandatory to use new tires purchased in 2026. Subscriptions with significant increase The registration fee increased significantly, from 15,000 to 55,000 yuan. This value now includes not only the two qualifying races, but also the test race, representing a substantial increase compared to previous seasons. In return, the organization ensures the unified transport of participating vehicles and eight tire/rim sets between the Guangdong International Circuit, where a significant part of the Macau teams are based, and the Zhuzhou International Circuit, in both directions. During the preparation event, each registered competitor will also be entitled to three nights' accommodation in Zhuzhou, in a three or four star hotel. Additionally, each competitor will benefit from support for official Pirelli tires, corresponding to an approximate value of 10,000 yuan.

item.title: Superbikes | Miguel Oliveira from last to seventh in the second race in Australia
item.description: Portuguese rider Miguel Oliveira (BMW) finished the second race of this opening weekend of the Superbike World Championship in seventh place, after starting from 21st and last place and from eighth place on Saturday. In a race held under rain, Miguel Oliveira finished 32.135 seconds behind the winner, the Italian Niccolo Bulega (Ducati), who beat his compatriot Axel Bassani (Bimota) by 11.336 seconds, with the Spaniard Alvaro Bautista (Ducati) in third, at 17.790. The Portuguese driver started at the back of the field after having mechanical problems in the last laps of the superpole race, held three hours earlier, which relegated him from the ninth place he occupied on the penultimate lap to 18th place. The second race was marked by rain, which fell heavily and caused six falls. The driver from Cascais, who usually does well on wet tracks, was already 10th in the middle of the race. Miguel Oliveira, who made his debut this weekend in the Superbike World Championship, after 14 years in MotoGP, still recovered to seventh place on the last lap, after overtaking Spaniard Iker Lecuona (Ducati) just a few meters from crossing the finish line. Italian Nicollo Bulega, favorite to start this 12-round championship, completed the perfect weekend, adding victory in the main race this Sunday, the 23rd of his career, to victories in the superpole and in the first race, on Saturday. It was the Italian driver's sixth consecutive victory in Australia. The 31-year-old Portuguese driver is eighth in the World Championship after this first of the 12 scheduled rounds, 45 behind the commander, Bulega, who has the maximum score (62) after this first round. The next race of the championship will be in Portugal, at the Autódromo Internacional do Algarve (AIA), in Portimão, on March 29th.

item.title: Kart: new INHAME competition is born in Macau
item.description: It is next weekend that the Coloane Kartdrome will host the first of seven rounds of the most recent championship integrated into the IAME international family of karting competitions, the IAME Series Macau After the MSAR established itself as a mandatory stop on the IAME Series Asia calendar and the Macau International Karting Grand Prix hosted the IAME Asia Final, the launch of the IAME Series Macau was confirmed, even before the New Lunar Year, comprising seven races to be held in Coloane. The calendar presented follows the already established AAMC Karting Championship. According to the brief communication released on social media by IAME Asia Series, “Macau’s motorsport heritage is profound and its passion for racing is recognized worldwide”. For the IAME promoter on the Asian continent, based in Singapore, taking the competition to the Macao SAR constitutes “another decisive step in the growth of karting in Asia-Pacific, creating more routes, more opportunities and a stronger community for young talents”. All the same The IAME Series are karting championships organized under the aegis of the Italian IAME (Italian American Motor Engineering), one of the world's largest manufacturers of engines for the sport. The IAME Series Asia calendar will also be expanded next year: in addition to the rounds in Malaysia and Thailand, Macau will host the fourth of six races of the season, scheduled for the 23rd and 24th of May. Regardless of country or region, all participants compete with IAME engines, under uniform technical regulations that ensure equal conditions on the track. The model prioritizes cost control and competition sustainability, placing emphasis on individual talent and sporting equity. In addition to Macau and the Asian championship, IAME already promotes competitions in Mainland China, Japan, Malaysia, Thailand, Sri Lanka, India and the Philippines. In this context, the organization believes that “together, we continue to build an interconnected platform across the region”. item.title: Lamborghini | Asian debut of the Temerario GT3 could be in Macau
item.description: Lamborghini said goodbye to the Huracán GT3 at the 2025 Macau Grand Prix and is now aiming for the Asian debut of the recently launched Temerario GT3, scheduled for November, on the streets of our city The ninth edition of the FIA ​​GT World Cup, scheduled for the 19th to 22nd of November at the Guia Circuit, appears as the likely stage for the debut on the Asian continent of the latest competition car from the Sant’Agata Bolognese brand, in a season in which the new twin-turbo V8 engine model will mainly be in a phase of competitive consolidation in Europe and the United States of America. Due to the limitations inherent in the production and delivery of new cars, Lamborghini Squadra Corse never seriously considered the introduction of the Temerario GT3 in the Asia-Pacific market in its launch year, despite the interest expressed by several teams, including JLOC, the formation of the Japanese Super GT championship that local driver André Couto represented. Even so, there is a clear desire on the part of Automobili Lamborghini's competition department to put its new GT3 on the track in Asia this year, precisely in the context of the Macau Grand Prix. “I can confirm that no Temerario will be entered in the GT World Challenge Asia or other regional championships,” explained a spokesperson for the Italian brand to the Portuguese portal SportMotores.com. "However, we are working on the FIA ​​GT World Cup in Macau, a race of enormous importance for us, where we intend to be present in the best possible way. At this stage, we cannot provide any further details." The possibility of Lamborghini competing this year in the Macao SAR race with the old Huracán GT3 is ruled out. The model faced difficulties in 2024 related to the introduction of the mandatory and controversial torque sensors. Edoardo Mortara had a particularly ungrateful weekend, seeing his third best time in Super Pole canceled for exceeding the maximum power limit, later ending up abandoning the main race when his car shut down. Production limitations Unlike other competition departments of major manufacturers, the Lamborghini Squadra Corse is a relatively small structure. The main limiting factor in the implementation of the Temerario GT3 this season, especially outside Europe, is related not only to the availability of units, but above all to the priority given to adequate technical support from the factory. The United States of America, where the car will make its competition debut at the 12 Hours of Sebring in March, continues to assume a strategic role for Lamborghini, hence the brand's full-time presence in the IMSA SportsCar Championship through the Pfaff Motorsports team. For the current season, Lamborghini Squadra Corse has allocated seven examples of the Temerario GT3 to competition in Europe, divided between the GT World Challenge Europe and the DTM. The Italian manufacturer plans to field three cars in the GT World Challenge Europe and four in the DTM. Mercedes-AMG evaluates return A ausência da Mercedes-AMG na edição do ano passado foi um dos temas mais comentados no paddock. This decision was justified by the lack of opportunities for Asian client teams to test the complex torque sensors, at a stage in which the Stuttgart brand is going through a demanding process of transitioning its sporting activities from HWA to the new subsidiary Affalterbach Racing. “At this stage, it is not possible to say whether a Mercedes-AMG GT3 will compete in the FIA ​​GT World Cup in Macau in 2026,” an official source from the German manufacturer, who maintains high interest in the MSAR event, told Hoje Macau. "The race is extremely appealing, both from a sporting and strategic point of view. We will carefully analyze the conditions at the appropriate time and evaluate them together with the interested teams." It should also be noted that the Macau Grand Prix could symbolize the definitive goodbye of the current Mercedes-AMG GT3, as the star brand is already developing the next generation of its car for the category, whose debut in competition could take place in 2027.

item.title: GP | The driver with the most victories in the history of the race has passed away
item.description: British John Macdonald passed away last week, aged 89, after a prolonged illness. He was the most successful driver in the history of the Macau Grand Prix and the only one to triumph on the Guia Circuit in both car and motorcycle races. The news was released on social media by his friend Eli Solomon, a historian and writer based in Singapore, who in recent years worked, together with Angus Lamont, on the production of the book “King of Macau”. The work portrays the life and career of Macdonald, who lived for decades in Hong Kong and was one of the central figures of motorsport in Southeast Asia in the 1960s and 1970s. "It is with deep sadness that I announce the passing of John Macdonald, which occurred on Sunday, January 25th, at the age of 89, after a prolonged illness. His mind remained as clear as ever, and he and Angus Lamont continued to work on King of Macau until the end of last year", wrote Eli Solomon, adding that "the final text was presented to him for approval at the end of last year, with the book expected to be ready for distribution this quarter, possibly in time for the deliveries in the UK for the Goodwood Members’ Meeting in April”. John Macdonald remains the only competitor to have won all the main races held on the Guia Circuit: four victories in the Macau Grand Prix (1965, 1972, 1973 and 1975), the triumph in the 1969 Macau Motorcycle Grand Prix and victory in the inaugural edition of the Macau Guia Race in 1972. However, his passion for motor sport was not limited to racing in circuit. After starting out on motorcycles in the United Kingdom, he participated in the 1962 Central African Rally, driving a Lancia B20, and in 1963 in the Scottish International Rally, in a Land Rover. That same year he moved to Hong Kong, where he joined the local police. Throughout his career he won three international rallies, two in Hong Kong and one in the Philippines, the country where he became National Champion in 1974. During his stay in Hong Kong, he was the owner of Camlex Garage, in Kowloon, after leaving Hutchinson, where he held the position of Group Service Director of Far East Motors, at the end of 1967. After retiring from business activity, he sold Camlex Garage, in 1981, to German Motors, owned by businessman and also pilot Herbert Adamczyk. Eternalized with the wax statue in the Macau Grand Prix Museum, Macdonald was also associated with the famous phrase: “Motor sport is the only truly exciting sport that can be practiced sitting down”. Sum of successes in Macau His debut at the Macau Grand Prix took place in 1964, with a sixth place at the wheel of a Lotus Elan, in what was his first experience in speed racing in cars. The following year he returned with a Lotus 18, a formula purchased for 7,000 patacas from the renowned Team Harper, and his performance at the wheel of an already aged single-seater was widely praised. After a race marked by incidents and some confusion, he took the checkered flag in first place and achieved the first of his six victories on the Guia Circuit. With the introduction of the Macau Motorcycle Grand Prix into the program in 1967, Macdonald could not resist taking part, also benefiting from the experience gained in the two-wheeled races he had competed in the United Kingdom at the end of the 1950s. In that debut year, marked by Japanese dominance, he did not stand out, but went on to win the race in 1969. His second victory at the Macau Grand Prix came in 1972, driving a Brabham BT36 ex-Graham Hill, after an absolutely dominating performance, crossing the finish line with a 30-second advantage over second place. On the same weekend he also won the first edition of the Macau Guia Race, in an Austin Mini Cooper S, a replica of which is now on display at the Macau Grand Prix Museum. With sponsorship and equipment to match his talent, he returned in 1973 to defend the Macau Grand Prix title, this time in a Brabham BT40, with which he had won in the Philippines and at the Malaysian city circuit of Penang, in addition to achieving third place in Singapore. After taking pole position, he became the first driver to win the race three times, also setting a new lap record. His fourth and final victory at the Macau Grand Prix came in 1975, nine years before the race adopted Formula 3 regulations, at the wheel of a Ralt RT1. Faced with the strongest opposition yet, Macdonald prevailed again, recording his final triumph in the competition. His last participation in the Macau Grand Prix occurred in 1976. His farewell to Grand Prix racing as a driver took place in May 1977, at the Penang Grand Prix, although in that same year he continued to be linked to Macau as a sponsor, giving his Ralt RT1 to Vern Schuppan. He left Hong Kong in 1983 and moved with his wife to Andorra. His last years of life were spent in Mauritius.
